revision.comment: /* See also */ removing [[Shoulder (engineering)]] redlink per [[WP:SEEALSO]] / removing redundant/unnecessary [[Groove (disambiguation)]] link
revision.text:
In [[manufacturing]] or [[mechanical engineering]] a '''groove''' is a long and narrow indentation built into a material, generally for the purpose of allowing another material or part to move within the groove and be guided by it. Examples include:
# A canal [[Machining|cut]] in a [[hardness|hard]] material, usually [[metal]]. This canal can be round, oval or an arc in order to receive another component such as a [[boss (engineering)|boss]], a tongue or a [[gasket]]. It can also be on the circumference of a [[Dowel#Machinery|dowel]], a [[Screw|bolt]], an [[axle]] or on the outside or inside of a [[Tubing (material)|tube]] or [[Pipe (material)|pipe]] etc. This canal may receive a [[circlip]] an [[o-ring]] or a gasket. # A depression on the entire [[circumference]] of a [[Casting|cast]] or [[Machining|machined]] [[wheel]], a [[pulley]] or [[Sheave (mechanical)|sheave]]. This depression may receive a [[Wire rope|cable]], a [[rope]] or a [[Belt (mechanical)|belt]]. # A longitudinal channel formed in a [[Hot rolling|hot rolled]] [[rail profile]] such as a [[Tramway track#Grooved rail|grooved rail]]. This groove is for the [[flange]] on a train wheel.
== See also == * [[Fluting (architecture)]] * [[Glass run channel]] * [[Labyrinth seal]] * [[Tongue and groove]] * [[Tread]]
[[Category:Metalworking terminology]]
{{Metalworking-stub}} {{mech-engineering-stub}}

revision.comment: replaced "due to" by "stated by" for the weak form of the conjecture, to avoid giving the impression that Stark and Trotter proved the weak conjecture.
revision.text:
In [[mathematics]], '''Hall's conjecture''' is an open question, {{As of|2015|lc=on}}, on the differences between [[Square number|perfect squares]] and [[perfect cube]]s. It asserts that a perfect square ''y''<sup>2</sup> and a perfect cube ''x''<sup>3</sup> that are not equal must lie a substantial distance apart. This question arose from consideration of the [[Mordell equation]] in the theory of [[integer point]]s on [[elliptic curve]]s.
The original version of Hall's conjecture, formulated by [[Marshall Hall, Jr.]] in 1970, says that there is a positive constant ''C'' such that for any integers ''x'' and ''y'' for which ''y''<sup>2</sup> ≠ ''x''<sup>3</sup>,
:<math> |y^2 - x^3| > C\sqrt{|x|}.</math>
Hall suggested that perhaps ''C'' could be taken as 1/5, which was consistent with all the data known at the time the conjecture was proposed. Danilov showed in 1982 that the exponent 1/2 on the right side (that is, the use of |''x''|<sup>1/2</sup>) can't be replaced by any higher power: for no δ > 0 is there a constant ''C'' such that |''y''<sup>2</sup> - ''x''<sup>3</sup>| > C|''x''|<sup>1/2 + δ</sup> whenever ''y''<sup>2</sup> ≠ ''x''<sup>3</sup>.
In 1965, Davenport proved an analogue of the above conjecture in the case of polynomials: if ''f''(''t'') and ''g''(''t'') are nonzero polynomials over '''C''' such that ''g''(''t'')<sup>3</sup> ≠ ''f''(''t'')<sup>2</sup> in '''C'''[''t''], then
:<math> \deg(g(t)^2 - f(t)^3) \geq \frac{1}{2}\deg f(t) + 1.</math>
The ''weak'' form of Hall's conjecture, stated by Stark and Trotter around 1980, replaces the square root on the right side of the inequality by any exponent ''less'' than 1/2: for any ''ε'' > 0, there is some constant ''c''(ε) depending on ε such that for any integers ''x'' and ''y'' for which ''y''<sup>2</sup> ≠ ''x''<sup>3</sup>,
:<math> |y^2 - x^3| > c(\varepsilon) x^{1/2-\varepsilon}.</math>
The original, ''strong'', form of the conjecture with exponent 1/2 has never been disproved, although it is no longer believed to be true and the term ''Hall's conjecture'' now generally means the version with the ε in it. For example, in 1998, [[Noam Elkies]] found the example
447884928428402042307918<sup>2</sup> - 5853886516781223<sup>3</sup> = -1641843,
for which compatibility with Hall's conjecture would require ''C'' to be less than .0214 ≈ 1/50, so roughly 10 times smaller than the original choice of 1/5 that Hall suggested.
The weak form of Hall's conjecture would follow from the [[ABC conjecture]].<ref>{{cite book | last=Schmidt | first=Wolfgang M. | authorlink=Wolfgang M. Schmidt | title=Diophantine approximations and Diophantine equations | series=Lecture Notes in Mathematics | volume=1467 | publisher=[[Springer-Verlag]] | year=1996 | edition=2nd | isbn=3-540-54058-X | zbl=0754.11020 | pages=205–206 }}</ref> A generalization to other perfect powers is [[Pillai's conjecture]].
==Notes== {{reflist}}
==References== * {{cite book |last=Guy | first=Richard K. | authorlink=Richard K. Guy | title=Unsolved problems in number theory | publisher=[[Springer-Verlag]] |edition=3rd | year=2004 |isbn=978-0-387-20860-2 | zbl=1058.11001 | at=D9 }} * {{cite book| last=Hall, Jr. | first=Marshall | year=1971 | chapter=The Diophantine equation ''x''<sup>3</sup> - ''y''<sup>2</sup> = ''k'' | pages=173–198 | title=Computers in Number Theory | editor1-first=A.O.L. | editor1-last=Atkin | editor1-link=A. O. L. Atkin | editor2-first=B. J. |editor2-last=Birch | editor2-link=Bryan John Birch | isbn=0-12-065750-3 | zbl=0225.10012}}
==External links== * [http://www.math.harvard.edu/~elkies/hall.html a page on the problem] by [[Noam Elkies]] * [http://ijcalvo.galeon.com/hall.htm table of good examples of Marshall Hall's conjecture] by Ismael Jimenez Calvo.
[[Category:Number theory]] [[Category:Conjectures]]

[[File:Knocked out.jpg|thumb|right|200px|TNA Knocked Out DVD by featuring [[Karen Jarrett]]]] '''Knockout''' is a term used by [[Impact Wrestling]] to refer to its female talent.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.tnawrestling.com/knockouts/ |title=Knockouts - The Ladies of TNA Wrestling |accessdate=2007-09-16 |publisher=Total Nonstop Action Wrestling|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071006094333/http://www.tnawrestling.com/knockouts/|archivedate=October 6, 2007}}</ref> The term is applied universally to [[professional wrestling|wrestlers]], backstage interviewers, and [[manager (professional wrestling)|managers/valets]].
==History== The term Knockouts is relatively new and was not used when Impact Wrestling (then known as NWA: Total Nonstop Action) debuted in 2002. The name originated from a DVD release in 2006 by the company, ''Knockouts: The Ladies of TNA Wrestling, Vol.1'', which focused on its then-current female stars. The name "Knockouts" as a catchall name for the women stuck after that. Female performers have been a part of TNA since the first national show,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://onlineworldofwrestling.com/results/tna/020619a.html |title=NWA:TNA weekly pay-per-view results - June 19, 2002 |accessdate=2007-09-16 |publisher=Online World of Wrestling}}</ref> which featured [[Mickie James|Alexis Laree]], [[Elektra (wrestling)|Elektra]], [[:imdbname:1752075|Erin Bray]], [[Francine Fournier|Francine]], [https://www.imdb.com/name/nm1750442/bio Miss Joni], Sasha, [[Daffney|Shannon]], [[Cathy Dingman|Taylor Vaughn]] and Teresa Tyler, as well as other female talent, including backstage interviewer [[Goldy Locks]] and valets [[Alicia Webb|Aleesha]] and [http://www.onlineworldofwrestling.com/profiles/s/seven-briggs.html Fluff Dupp]. [[Cynthia Lynch|Bobcat]] also debuted as a valet in a match that was taped during the first PPV, but aired during the second PPV.
===Miss TNA (2002)=== A Lingerie Battle Royal to crown the first 'Miss TNA' was taped during the very first NWA:TNA weekly PPV on June 19, 2002, and was aired during the second PPV on June 26, 2002.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.onlineworldofwrestling.com/results/tna/2002.html |title=NWA:TNA 2002 Results |accessdate=2007-11-20 |publisher=Online World of Wrestling}}</ref> [[Cathy Dingman|Taylor Vaughn]] won the first Miss TNA crown.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.wrestleview.com/messages1/2024.shtml |title=TNA PPV results 6/26 |accessdate=2007-10-15 |publisher=WrestleView}}</ref> She defended the title against Francine, who soon afterward abandoned her pursuit of the title and engaged in a brief feud with [[Jasmin St. Claire]]. Vaughn lost the title when she was defeated by male character [[Allan Funk|Bruce]] a few weeks later. Although male, he claimed that he should be entitled to wrestle for the Miss TNA crown because he was gay.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.wrestleview.com/news/1028817969.shtml|title=NWA:TNA weekly pay-per-view results - July 08, 2002 |accessdate=2007-09-16 |publisher=WrestleView}}</ref> Bruce held the crown for three months and during his time as Miss TNA he attacked many female wrestlers and fans, enraging the male stars of TNA including Jorge Estrada. The two then had a singles match with the stipulation that if Estrada won, [https://www.imdb.com/name/nm1750442/bio Priscilla] would become the new Miss TNA.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.wrestleview.com/news/1036645751.shtml |title=NWA:TNA weekly pay-per-view results - 11th September, 2002 |accessdate=2007-10-16 |publisher=WrestleView}}</ref> Although Estrada won the match, the crown didn't change hands because he won by disqualification. In the next weeks, Bruce's tag team partner, [[Lenny Lane|Lenny]], tried to get Bruce injured (since the runner-up would then take over the crown should the champion be injured).<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.wrestleview.com/news/1037252142.shtml |title=NWA:TNA weekly pay-per-view results - 13th November, 2002 |accessdate=2007-10-16 |publisher=WrestleView}}</ref> This led to the breakup of ''The Rainbow Express'', and Bruce's homosexuality was questioned by backstage interviewer [[Goldy Locks]], who claimed she had seen him in the shower with [http://www.onlineworldofwrestling.com/profiles/a/april-pennington.html April Pennington]. The storyline soon came to a close due to poor crowd reception, with Pennington and Goldylocks walking off together holding hands, as Lenny and Bruce fought over Pennington.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.tv.com/tna-pay-per-view/november-13-2002/episode/255485/recap.html |title=TNA Pay-Per-View: November 13, 2002 Recap |accessdate=2007-11-20 |publisher=TV.com}}</ref> The storyline ended with Bruce declaring himself straight and handing his crown over to Pennington. The Miss TNA crown wasn't mentioned on-screen afterward. Throughout 2002, TNA also featured Belladonna in a valet role and former ''[[WWE Tough Enough]]'' contestant [http://www.onlineworldofwrestling.com/profiles/p/paulina.html Paulina] as a bodyguard.
===Post–Miss TNA (2003–2006)=== Women's wrestling continued to be a feature of the weekly PPVs before an official women's division was established in 2007. In 2003, cage dancers (many of whom were independent female wrestlers who were then unknown at the time, including [[Jaime Lynne|Lollipop]]) were used near the top of the entrance ramp, but this concept was abandoned shortly after its conception. One of TNA's early controversial moments ensued on the March 12, 2003 pay-per-view when Lollipop had her top ripped off during a catfight with [[Sports Entertainment Extreme|S.E.X.]] member [http://www.onlineworldofwrestling.com/profiles/h/holly-wood.html Holly Wood] and exposed her breasts throughout the fight. TNA also featured [[ring girl]] [http://www.onlineworldofwrestling.com/profiles/a/athena.html Athena] in many feuds and altercations.
From 2003-2004, TNA regularly used several female wrestlers on their PPVs and television programs, including [[Trinity (wrestler)|Trinity]], [[Kim Nielsen (wrestler)|Desire]], [[Mickie James|Alexis Laree]], [[Traci Brooks]], [[Cheerleader Melissa]], [[Veronica Stevens|Nurse Veronica]] (who also competed as Simply Luscious), and [[Elizabeth Miklosi|Cheerleader Valentina]] (who also competed as JV Love); however, they were often primarily depicted as [[manager (professional wrestling)|valets]] who occasionally wrestled. Of all the women utilized at this time, Trinity was the most active in the ring, as she feuded with Desire, Alexis Laree, and Traci Brooks, as well as competed in the [[X Division]]. During this time, TNA also briefly featured an all-female faction named "[[Bitchslap (professional wrestling)|Bitchslap]]" that consisted of Nurse Veronica, Traci Brooks, Cheerleader Valentina, and Trinity (who only appeared twice with the group). They were engaged in a feud with TNA dancers Lollipop and April Pennington.
Independent female wrestlers were frequently featured on ''[[TNA Xplosion]]'' and occasionally on TNA pay-per-views, including [[Angelina Love|Angel Williams]] (who would later return as Angelina Love), [[April Hunter]], Brandi Wine, [[Daizee Haze]], [[Daffney|Lucy]] (who previously competed as Shannon and would later return as Daffney), [[Malia Hosaka]], [[Mercedes Martinez]], [[MsChif]], and [[ODB (wrestler)|ODB]] (who also wrestled as Poison).
TNA briefly recognized the [[NWA World Women's Championship]] in 2003. On March 12, 2003, [[Leilani Kai]] defeated [[Madison (wrestler)|Madison]] to win the NWA World Women's Championship in a dark match on a TNA pay-per-view.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://ladysports.com/nashville.htm |title=Explosion in Nashville |accessdate=2007-11-20 |publisher=LadySports |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081225183858/http://ladysports.com/nashville.htm |archivedate=2008-12-25 |df= }}</ref> On April 19, 2003, Kai defended the title against Desire at a house show, but she was later stripped of the title by NWA President Bill Behrens due to missing several subsequent NWA shows. According to Kai, she skipped the shows because she felt the NWA governing board was not treating the Women's Championship with the respect it deserved, such as not televising title matches on the TNA pay-per-views and ''[[TNA Xplosion]]''.
Fewer women's matches were featured toward the end of 2004 and throughout 2005; however, TNA did feature pay-per-view matches pitting Trinity against former WWE Diva [[Jacqueline Moore|Jacqueline]] and Traci Brooks. TNA also featured [[Stephanie Bellars|Minsa]] in an on-air non-wrestling role.
Following the debut of the ''[[TNA Impact!|TNA iMPACT!]]'' television program in 2005, TNA featured former WWE Divas such as [[Gail Kim]], [[Jackie Gayda]], and [[Christy Hemme]], as well as independent female wrestler [[Jaime Dauncey|Sirelda]] in prominent on-air roles and feuds. Although most of the prior female talent had left TNA by this time, Traci Brooks remained in an on-air role and TNA added a new ring girl, [[SoCal Val]] (replacing Athena) and backstage interviewer, [[Leticia Cline]] (replacing Goldy Locks). Gail Kim competed in a few matches that were televised and/or taped throughout 2006 against Sirelda and Traci Brooks, while independent wrestler [[Amber O'Neal]] competed at TNA house shows in matches against Kim and Jacqueline. In the fall of 2006, [[Sherri Martel]] appeared on ''TNA iMPACT!'' in her final televised appearance before her death the following year.
===Impact Wrestling Knockouts Division (2007–present)=== [[File:Gail_Kim_Jan_2013.jpg|thumb|185px|left|upright|Inaugural [[TNA Knockouts Championship|TNA Knockouts Champion]], [[Gail Kim]]]] The formation of an official women's division began at ''[[Final Resolution#2007|Final Resolution]]'' in 2007 as TNA spent the early part of the year building up the feud between Gail Kim and Jacqueline, who made her on-air return at the pay-per-view also during the summer a feud between Christy Hemme and [[Nicole Raczynski|Roxxi Laveaux]] took place. The first [[TNA Women's Knockout Championship|TNA Women's Knockout Champion]] was crowned on October 14, 2007, at ''[[Bound for Glory (2007)|Bound for Glory]]'' in a 10–Knockout gauntlet match which Gail Kim won with lastly eliminating Roxxi Laveaux.<ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xiswjFPvUNY&feature=em-uploademail Girl Talk with Christy Hemme, Velvet Sky and ODB at the Arena that started Knockouts division - [[Arena at Gwinnett Center]]]</ref> Around this time, TNA signed several additional female wrestlers and personalities, including [[Angelina Love|Angel Williams]], [[Kia Stevens|Amazing Kong]], [[ODB (wrestler)|ODB]], [[Shelly Martinez]], and [[Velvet Sky|Talia Madison]] who were then renamed after the PPV, as well as valet [[Karen Jarrett]] and new backstage interviewer [[Crystal Louthan]]. In a stark departure to TNA's past programming where their female talent were often promoted as [[Attractiveness|eye candy]] with little to no emphasis on athleticism or wrestling ability, in the same fashion as their WWE Diva counterparts during that time period, TNA's women's division emphasized on serious wrestling competition between their female talent, as well as their credibility on par with their male counterparts.<ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=pv3wgrPT0zU TNA Knockout TV Advert]</ref> Since the inception of an official championship, matches and segments involving the Knockouts have contributed to drawing some of the better ratings of Impact shows.<ref>[http://pwtorch.com/artman2/publish/TNA_News_1/article_25786.shtml PWTorch - WWE News and Pro Wrestling Coverage Since 1987<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
Since 2008, TNA continued to expand the women's division by featuring various prospective independent talents, veterans, and reality show winners such as [[Sharmell Sullivan-Huffman|Sharmell]], [[Taylor Wilde]], [[Daffney]], [[Lisa Marie Varon|Tara]], [[Ayako Hamada|Hamada]], [[Sarah Stock|Sarita]], [[Mickie James]], and ''[[Survivor: The Amazon]]'' winner Jenna Morasca while Lauren Brooke became the new backstage interviewer at Lockdown and [[Daizee Haze]] who appeared in the first few years of the company returned in a one time match on May 1st losing to [[Cheerleader Melissa]] who was also pulling dual role under the Raisha Saeed gimmick at that time.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://pwtorch.com/artman2/publish/TNA_News_1/article_43965.shtml|title=TNA News: Former WWE women's champion reportedly signs with TNA; when she's expected to debut|date=2010-09-22|last=Caldwell|first=James|accessdate=2010-10-01|work=Pro Wrestling Torch}}</ref>
[[File:Sarah Stock & Shantelle Malawski.jpg|thumb|185px|right|upright|[[Sarah Stock|Sarita]] and [[Taylor Wilde]], the first [[TNA Knockouts Tag Team Championship|TNA Knockouts Tag Team Champions]]]] The division would see the start of many various changes when in August, Gail Kim's contract with TNA expired and instead of renewing it, she decided to return to rival [[World Wrestling Entertainment|WWE]] for a second run. At the start of the following year in 2009, [[Madison Rayne]] debuted in TNA on January 8th and became the third member of [[The Beautiful People (professional wrestling)|The Beautiful People]] alongside existing members Angelina Love and Velvet Sky which made the tag team a stable and the [[TNA Knockouts Tag Team Championship]] was introduced at ''[[No Surrender (2009)|No Surrender]]'' and Sarita and Taylor Wilde became the first [[TNA Knockouts Tag Team Championship|TNA Knockouts Tag Team Champions]] when they won the final match of an eight–team tournament.
The women’s division would see a start of vast departures in fall of 2009 beginning when Angelina Love left the company on September 3rd due to visa work issue, Love was replaced by Lacey Von Erich in the Beautiful People stable and then immediately returned to the company the following year on January 14. Later on, Awesome Kong, Alissa Flash, Roxxi, Traci Brooks, Roxxi, ODB, and Tara (although would return two months later on July 11th at [[Victory Road (2010)|Victory Road]]) all departed from the company mutually or due to controversial circumstances. Madison Rayne made history by becoming the first person to hold both the Women's Knockout Championship and the Knockouts Tag Team Championship simultaneously at [[Lockdown (2010)|Lockdown]]. On August 8th, Francine appeared in a pre-taped interview at the ECW reunion themed Hardcore Justice and Lacey Von Erich, Hamada, and Taylor Wilde departed from the company at the end of the year. Despite departures during this time period, the division continued to grow.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://pwtorch.com/artman2/publish/TNA_News_1/article_35021.shtml|title=TNA News: Top star in the TNA Knockouts division released|date=2009-09-04|accessdate=2009-09-04|last=Caldwell|first=James|publisher=PWTorch}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.f4wonline.com/content/view/10694/|title=Lineup for TNA Impact tapings tomorrow night/TNA signs member of famous family to debut this week|accessdate=2009-09-21|publisher=Wrestling Observer}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://pwtorch.com/artman2/publish/PPV_Reports_5/article_40727.shtml|title=TNA Lockdown Results 4/18: Keller's live ongoing PPV report with commentary - Team Hogan vs. Team Flair|first=Wade|last=Keller|date=2010-04-18|accessdate=2010-04-18|publisher=Pro Wrestling Torch}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://pwtorch.com/artman2/publish/tnappvs/article_42979.shtml|title=Caldwell's TNA Hardcore Justice PPV results 8/8: Ongoing "virtual time" coverage of ECW-themed PPV headlined by RVD vs. Sabu|first=James|last=Caldwell|date=2010-08-08|accessdate=2010-08-08|work=Pro Wrestling Torch}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://pwtorch.com/artman2/publish/TNA_News_1/article_45229.shtml|title=TNA News: TNA Knockout announcers her departure from the company effective today|date=2010-11-11|accessdate=2010-11-11|last=Caldwell|first=James|work=Pro Wrestling Torch}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wrestleview.com/viewnews.php?id=1291690239 |title=TNA vacates titles at Impact TV tapings tonight |first=Adam |last=Martin |date=2010-12-06 |accessdate=2010-12-09 |work=WrestleView |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101216165927/http://www.wrestleview.com/viewnews.php?id=1291690239 |archivedate=2010-12-16 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wrestleview.com/viewnews.php?id=1291929792|title=Report: Another Knockout done with TNA for now|first=Adam|last=Martin|date=2010-12-09|accessdate=2010-12-09|work=WrestleView}}</ref>
[[File:Knockout Champion Velvet Sky.jpg|thumb|right|180px|alt=|Velvet Sky as the [[TNA Knockouts Championship|TNA Knockouts Champion]]]] [[File:Brooke Tessmacher Knockout Tag Champion.jpg|thumb|left|upright|Miss Tessmacher with the [[TNA Knockouts Tag Team Championship]]]]
Despite initially departing the company in individual time periods, Angelina Love, Velvet Sky, Awesome Kong, Alissa Flash, Traci Brooks, Roxxi, ODB, Jacqueline, SoCal Val, Mickie James, Thea Trinidad, Karen Jarrett, Christy Hemme, Taryn Terrell, Brooke, Katarina, and Madison Rayne would return to the company in later years either full-time or short lived runs and through special appearances.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wrestleview.com/viewnews.php?id=1297755371 |title=Spoilers: TNA Impact tapings for February 17 |date=2011-02-15 |accessdate=2011-02-15 |last=Martin |first=Adam |work=WrestleView |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110219115348/http://www.wrestleview.com/viewnews.php?id=1297755371 |archivedate=2011-02-19 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wrestleview.com/viewnews.php?id=1297877544|title=Spoilers: TNA Impact tapings for February 24|last=Martin|first=Adam|date=2011-02-16|work=WrestleView|accessdate=2011-03-15}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://pwtorch.com/artman2/publish/TNA_News_1/article_48033.shtml|title=TNA News: Impact spoilers 3/10 - Detailed report from N.C. on the Impact episode leading to the Victory Road PPV|date=2011-02-15|accessdate=2011-03-15|last=Cavender|first=Shawn|work=Pro Wrestling Torch}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wrestleview.com/viewnews.php?id=1300201595 |title=Spoilers: TNA Impact for March 17th |date=2011-03-15 |accessdate=2011-03-15 |last=Gerweck |first=Steve |work=WrestleView |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110318060117/http://www.wrestleview.com/viewnews.php?id=1300201595 |archivedate=2011-03-18 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wrestleview.com/viewnews.php?id=1305599541 |title=Spoilers: Impact Wrestling for May 19 |last=Tedesco |first=Mike |date=2011-05-16 |accessdate=2011-06-14 |work=WrestleView |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110531053801/http://www.wrestleview.com/viewnews.php?id=1305599541 |archivedate=2011-05-31 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wrestleview.com/viewnews.php?id=1308026713|title=Spoilers: Impact Wrestling for June 16|last=Tedesco|first=Mike|date=2011-06-14|accessdate=2011-06-14|work=WrestleView}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://pwtorch.com/artman2/publish/wadekellerdotcom/51592.shtml|title=Keller's TNA Impact Wrestling report 7/21: Ongoing "virtual time" report on Sting title win fallout|last=Keller|first=Wade|authorlink=Wade Keller|date=2011-07-21|accessdate=2011-07-21|work=Pro Wrestling Torch}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wrestleview.com/viewnews.php?id=1322526190|title=Jackie Moore's TNA contract has expired|date=2011-11-28|accessdate=2011-11-28|last=Tedesco|first=Mike|work=WrestleView}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.twitlonger.com/show/h0nn61|title=Yes it's true my time w Tna has come to an end&what;a great time I had. I love the Tna family and will miss everyone but will be watching every thurs!|last=Brookshaw|first=Tracy|date=2012-04-17|accessdate=2012-04-17|publisher=[[Twitter]]}}</ref>
In the years of 2011-2013 in which on March 15, 2011, Daffney's contract with TNA expired and was not renewed.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wrestleview.com/viewnews.php?id=1300214235|title=Knockout files claim against TNA, deal not renewed|first=Adam|last=Martin|date=2011-03-15|accessdate=2011-03-15|work=WrestleView}}</ref> then 7 months later, Gail Kim returned to TNA, after spending the past three years with WWE during her second run.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://pwtorch.com/artman2/publish/quicknews/article_54376.shtml|title=Impact Spoiler Pic - Former WWE Diva returns|date=2011-10-18|accessdate=2011-10-18|work=Pro Wrestling Torch}}</ref> [[Taeler Hendrix]] was signed to a contract through the company's [[TNA Gut Check|Gut Check Challenge]], becoming the first ever woman to win the contest and in August 2012, [[Taryn Terrell]] joined the division as the official referee although later on would be transitioned into an active role to receive a push to feud with Gail Kim.<ref>{{cite web|last=Boutwell|first=Josh|title=TNA Impact Wrestling Results - 3/21/13 (#1 Contender Match)|url=http://www.wrestleview.com/tna-wrestling-results/tna-impact-results/40456-tna-impact-wrestling-results-3-21-13-4-way-1-contender-match|publisher=Wrestleview|accessdate=March 21, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://pwtorch.com/artman2/publish/tnaimpact/article_64338.shtml|title=Caldwell's TNA Impact results 8/16: Ongoing "virtual-time" coverage of live Impact - Hardcore Justice fall-out, three BFG Series matches|last=Caldwell|first=James|date=2012-08-16|accessdate=2012-08-16|work=Pro Wrestling Torch}}</ref> Sarita departed from TNA entering the year of 2013 after her contract would expire.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pwinsider.com/article/74550/another-tna-departure-confirmed.html?p=1|title=Another TNA departure confirmed|last=Johnson|first=Mike|date=2013-01-09|accessdate=2013-01-09|work=Pro Wrestling Insider}}</ref> [[Lei'D Tapa]] became the second female talent signed to a contract through the [[TNA Gut Check|Gut Check Challenge]]. In the summer, the [[TNA Knockouts Tag Team Championship]] would be deactivated when on the June 20, 2013 episode of ''Impact Wrestling'', Knockouts Division Executive [[Brooke Hogan]] stripped ODB and Eric Young of the title because Young was a male talent. This ultimately resulted in the titles being no longer being listed among TNA's active championships.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.impactwrestling.com/roster/Wrestler-Roster |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2013-07-05 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130703175045/http://www.impactwrestling.com/roster/Wrestler-Roster |archivedate=2013-07-03 |df= }}</ref> The women’s division would see again the start of vast departures when [[Valerie Wyndham|SoCal Val]], [[Madison Rayne]], [[Lisa Marie Varon|Tara]], [[Mickie James]], and [[Taeler Hendrix]] all departed from the company entering the month of July to mid-Fall mutually; Rayne was originally granted a maternity leave in early March due to real life pregnancy, Hendrix's departure made [[Lei'D Tapa]] the only female talent signed from the short-lived [[TNA Gut Check|Gut Check Challenge]], and SoCal Val's departure left [[Christy Hemme]] as the longest tenured female talent within the company.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://pwinsider.com/article/78678/tna-releases-knockout.html?p=1|title=TNA releases Knockout|publisher=Pro Wrestling Insider|accessdate=July 3, 2013}}</ref><ref>http://www.pwinsider.com/ViewArticle.php?id=78970</ref> The vast departures lead to [[Christy Hemme]], [[Gail Kim]], [[Velvet Sky]], [[ODB (wrestler)|ODB]], [[Brooke Tessmacher|Brooke]], [[Taryn Terrell]], [[Lei'D Tapa]], [[The Blossom Twins|Hannah Blossom]], [[The Blossom Twins|Holly Blossom]], [[Rebel (wrestler)|Rebel]], and [[Santana Garrett|Brittany]] remaining and continuing on with the company. [[Taryn Terrell]] would be granted a maternity leave in August due to real life pregnancy.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://nodq.com/tna/383624811.shtml |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2013-10-16 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131016195003/http://nodq.com/tna/383624811.shtml |archivedate=2013-10-16 |df= }}</ref> [[Madison Rayne]] would return to the company in late November after departing from the company earlier in the March.<ref>{{cite web|last=Caldwell|first=James|title=CALDWELL'S TNA IMPACT RESULTS 12/12: Ongoing "virtual-time" coverage of TNA Impact - Feast or Fired, X Title match, more|url=http://pwtorch.com/artman2/publish/tnaimpact/article_75081.shtml|publisher=PWTorch|accessdate=December 12, 2013}}</ref>
[[File:AngelinaLove1.JPG|thumb|185px|right|upright|[[Angelina Love]], the first 6-times Knockouts Champion]] [[Angelina Love]] would win the Knockouts Championship at the [[Sacrifice (2014)|Sacrifice]] pay-per-view for a record-breaking sixth time<ref>{{cite web|last=Johnson|first=Mike|title=FORMER KNOCKOUTS CHAMPION RETURNING TONIGHT|url=http://www.pwinsider.com/article/84238/former-knockouts-champion-returning-tonight.html?p=1|publisher=PWInsider|accessdate=14 March 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Johnson|first=Mike|title=SPOILER: THE RETURNING FORMER TNA KNOCKOUTS CHAMPION IS...|url=http://www.pwinsider.com/article/84249/spoiler-the-returning-former-tna-knockouts-champion-is.html?p=1|publisher=PWInsider|accessdate=14 March 2014}}</ref> A few days later, Lei'D Tapa departed from the company after her contract expired.<ref>{{cite web|last=Tapa|first=Lei'D|title=When 1 door closes another door opens! Thank you @IMPACTWRESTLING for giving me the opportunity! To my fans I luv u all!! #BowDown|url=https://twitter.com/LeiD_Tapa/statuses/446831493843660800|publisher=Twitter|accessdate=21 March 2014}}</ref><ref name=BFFs>{{cite web|last=Carapola|first=Stuart|title=COMPLETE IMPACT WRESTLING REPORT: THE TWITTER MACHINE IS BACK, THE WOLVES PICK UP A VERY BIG WIN, A LONG AND BRUTAL FIGHT BETWEEN BULLY RAY AND BOBBY ROODE, VELVET IS FORCED TO CHOOSE, EC3 SEARCHES FOR WILLOW, GUNNER AND STORM FACE OFF IN AN ANYTHING GOES MATCH, AND MORE|url=http://www.pwinsider.com/article/84576/complete-impact-wrestling-report-the-twitter-machine-is-back-the-wolves-pick-up-a-very-big-win-a-long-and-brutal-fight-between-bully-ray-and-bobby-roode-velvet-is-forced-to-choose-ec3-searches-for-willow-gunner-and-storm-face-off-in-an-anything-goes-match-and-more.html?p=1|publisher=PWInsider|accessdate=28 March 2014}}</ref><ref name=ReturnofBPs>{{cite web|last=Carapola|first=Stuart|title=ONGOING IMPACT WRESTLING REPORT: KEN ANDERSON AND SAMUEL SHAW BREAK THEIR TIE WITH A STRAITJACKET MATCH, KENNY KING MAKES A BIG GRAB FOR GLORY, MAGNUS HAS A VERY SPECIAL MESSAGE FOR ABYSS, THE BEAUTIFUL PEOPLE TEAM ON IMPACT FOR THE FIRST TIME IN YEARS|url=http://www.pwinsider.com/article/84736/ongoing-impact-wrestling-report-ken-anderson-and-samuel-shaw-break-their-tie-with-a-straitjacket-match-kenny-king-makes-a-big-grab-for-glory-magnus-has-a-very-special-message-for-abyss-the-beautiful-people-team-on-impact-for-the-first-time-in-years.html?p=1|publisher=PWInsider|accessdate=4 April 2014}}</ref><ref name=6KnockoutsTitle>{{cite web|last=Martin|first=Adam|title=TNA Sacrifice PPV Results - 4/27/14 (Live results from Orlando)|url=http://www.wrestleview.com/tna-sacrifice-ppv/48189-tna-sacrifice-ppv-results-4-27-14-live-results-from-orlando|publisher=Wrestleview|accessdate=28 April 2014}}</ref> Throughout August, vignettes hyping the debut of [[Jessicka Havok|Havok]] would air on ''Impact Wrestling''.<ref>http://www.wrestlezone.com/news/506185-update-on-the-wolves-tna-contracts-havok-is-coming-next-week</ref> Havok made her debut by attacking Gail Kim and Taryn Terrell after their title match on the September 3 broadcast of ''Impact Wrestling''.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Caldwell|first1=James|title=CALDWELL'S TNA IMPACT REPORT 9/3: TNA Champ vs. X Division champ, #1 contender matches, KO Title match, more|url=http://pwtorch.com/artman2/publish/tnaimpact/article_80571.shtml|website=pwtorch.com|publisher=PWTorch|accessdate=5 September 2014}}</ref> During the tapings of ''Impact Wrestling'' on September 16, Havok defeated Kim in the main event of ''Impact Wrestling'' to win the TNA Women's Knockout Championship for the first time; the match aired on [[broadcast delay|tape delay]] on October 1.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wrestleview.com/tna-news/50787-spoilers-early-notes-from-9-16-impact-wrestling-taping|title=Spoiler: Early notes from 9/16 Impact Wrestling taping|date=September 17, 2014|last=Martin|first=Adam|accessdate=September 17, 2014|publisher=WrestleView}}</ref> Havok lost the championship three days later to Taryn Terrell in a three-way match that also involved Gail Kim; the match aired on tape delay on November 19.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wrestleview.com/tna-news/50828-spoilers-9-19-impact-wrestling-tapings-in-bethlehem|title=Spoilers: 9/19 Impact Wrestling tapings in Bethlehem|date=September 20, 2014|last=Martin|first=Adam|accessdate=September 21, 2014|publisher=WrestleView}}</ref>
Towards the end of the year of 2015 in October, for the first time ever, the TNA Knockouts entered a tournament for the vacant [[TNA World Heavyweight Championship]]; Awesome Kong, Gail Kim, Madison Rayne, and Brooke were revealed to being the representatives of the women's division in the group.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://pwtorch.com/artman2/publish/tnaimpact/article_87906.shtml#.Vhj-LPntmkp|title=MCMAHON'S TNA IMPACT REPORT 10/7: TNA Title Series kicks off, Bound for Glory fall-out, more; Overall Reax|website=PWTorch|author=Mike McMahon|date=September 16, 2015|accessdate=September 17, 2015}}</ref> Brooke announced her departure from the company on November 24th.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pwinsider.com/article/97855/former-tna-champion-says-goodbye-.html?p=1|title=FORMER TNA CHAMPION SAYS GOODBYE|author=Scherer, Dave|website=PWInsider|date=November 15, 2015|accessdate=November 24, 2015}}</ref> On December 29, just weeks before TNA's début on ''[[Pop (U.S. TV network)|Pop TV]]'', [[Maria Kanellis]] signed with the company.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Johnson|first1=Mike|title=TWO STARS DEPART RING OF HONOR|url=http://pwinsider.com/article/98555/two-stars-depart-ring-of-honor.html|website=Pro Wrestling Insider|accessdate=December 20, 2015|date=December 20, 2015}}</ref> At [[Bound for Glory (2016)|Bound for Glory]], [[Awesome Kong]], [[Taryn Terrell]], and [[Christy Hemme]] made a special appearance to induct Gail Kim in the [[TNA Hall of Fame]]. Throughout 2016, the division included various competitors who just joined the company. Most of them had title reigns with the Knockouts Championship, such as [[Mia Yim|Jade]],<ref>{{cite web|title=March IMPACT Taping Results|url=http://www.tnasylum.net/home/march-impact-taping-results|website=TNAsylum|date=March 17, 2016|accessdate=March 17, 2016}}</ref> [[Allysin Kay|Sienna]]<ref name="TNASlammiversary2016">{{cite web|last=Caldwell|first=James|title=6/12 TNA Slammiversary PPV Results – CALDWELL’S Complete Report|url=http://www.pwtorch.com/site/2016/06/12/tnaslammfinalresults/|work=Pro Wrestling Torch|accessdate=June 12, 2016}}</ref> and [[Cherry Bomb|Allie]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Spoilers: TNA Impact Wrestling Taping Results From 8/12/16|url=http://www.pwmania.com/spoilers-tna-impact-wrestling-taping-results-from-81216|work=pwmania.com|accessdate=14 August 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Bocook|first=Gerald|title=TNA Impact Wrestling Results – 8/25/16 (EC3 vs. Drew Galloway, new TNA Knockouts Champion)|url=http://www.wrestleview.com/tna-wrestling-results/tna-impact-results/66333-tna-impact-wrestling-results-82516-ec3-vs-drew-galloway-headlines-new-tna-knockouts-champion/|publisher=WrestleView|accessdate=August 26, 2016}}</ref> In 2017, at [[Slammiversary XV]], Sienna defeated [[Rosemary (wrestler)|Rosemary]] in a [[Championship unification|unification match]] which saw the TNA Knockouts and [[GFW Women's Championship|GFW Women's]] championships get unified. During Sienna's reign the title was renamed to ''Impact Wrestling Knockouts Championship''.<ref>{{cite web|title=7/2 Powell's GFW/Impact Wrestling Slammiversary live review: Lashley vs. Alberto El Patron to unify the GFW and Impact Wrestling Championships, Scott Steiner and Josh Mathews vs. Jeremy Borash and Joseph Park, Sonjay Dutt vs. Low Ki in a best of three falls match for the X Division Championship|url=http://prowrestling.net/site/2017/07/02/72-powells-gfwimpact-wrestling-slammiversary-live-review-lashley-vs-alberto-el-patron-unify-gfw-impact-wrestling-championships-scott-steiner-josh-mathews-vs-jeremy-borash-jos/|last=Powell|first=Jason|work=Pro Wrestling Dot Net|date=July 2, 2017|accessdate=July 2, 2017}}</ref> Shortly after, at [[Bound for Glory (2017)|Bound for Glory]], Gail Kim won the title for the record–setting seventh time and also became the first woman to [[retirement|retire]] while holding the title. After Kim's retirement, [[Laurel Van Ness]] defeated Rosemary to win the championship for the first time. In mid–2018, [[Su Yung]] would capture the title from Allie in a [[Casket Match|last rites match]], only a month after she joined Impact Wrestling.
==Knockouts Division authority figure== In August 2008, it was announced on ''TNAwrestling.com'' that Traci Brooks was officially in charge of the Knockouts Division as the [[Professional wrestling authority figures#Total Nonstop Action Wrestling authority figures|Knockouts Division Commissioner]], also known as the "Knockout Law". On screen credit was given to [[Jim Cornette]] (at the time, the highest position of on-screen authority the fans saw), who was fed up with the Knockouts, and needed someone who "spoke their language" to control them. In January 2009, Brooks stopped appearing in TNA and Cornette resumed control over the Knockout division. Brooks returned on the March 12, 2009, edition of ''Impact!'' as a referee. She was released on March 4, 2010. Since the year of 2009, there has been five female talents who were appointed the role of authority figure in the women's division.

9/1/11 |date=2011-09-02 |accessdate=2011-09-02 |last=Boutwell |first=Josh |work=WrestleView |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121003051411/http://www.wrestleview.com/viewnews.php?id=1314968579 |archivedate=2012-10-03 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://pwtorch.com/artman2/publish/tnaimpact/article_56050.shtml|title=Caldwell's TNA Impact Wrestling report 12/15: PPV fall-out, Jarrett firing, Hardy-Ray|last=Caldwell|first=James|date=2011-12-15|accessdate=2011-12-15|work=Pro Wrestling Torch}}</ref> |- |[[Brooke Hogan]] |May 31, 2012 — August 16, 2013 |''[[TNA iMPACT|Impact Wrestling]]'' |Appointed as the Vice President of the Knockouts by her father, former Impact General Manager [[Hulk Hogan]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.impactwrestling.com/news/item/3525-Brooke-Hogan-To-Join-IMPACT-WRESTLING-On-SpikeTV-On-May-31|title=Brooke Hogan Joins Impact Wrestling This Thursday Live On SpikeTV|accessdate=2012-05-28|work=[[Total Nonstop Action Wrestling]]}}</ref> |- |[[Maria Kanellis-Bennett]] |April 19, 2016 — September 8, 2016 |''[[TNA iMPACT|Impact Wrestling]]'' |Won a six–way [[ladder match]] made by on-screen executive Billy Corgan to receive full control as Leader of the Knockouts Division |- |}
==Promotion== The popularity of women in TNA has resulted cross-promotion with other brands featuring the TNA Knockouts.
===TNA Knockout DVDs and Television specials=== [[File:KnockoutsDVD.jpg|thumb|right|175px|''Knockouts: The Ladies of TNA Wrestling'']] *In 2006, TNA released the first Knockouts DVD entitled '''''Knockouts: The Ladies of TNA Wrestling''''' which featured [[Christy Hemme]], [[Gail Kim]], [[Jackie Gayda]], [[SoCal Val]], and [[Traci Brooks]]; much similar to their rival company female talent, this video release was the first and only DVD where the Knockouts were featured in select outdoor locations. *In 2008, TNA released their second Knockouts DVD on October 7, 2008 entitled '''''TNA Knockouts: Knocked Out''''' which featured [[Angelina Love]], [[Kia Stevens|Awesome Kong]], [[Christy Hemme]], [[Gail Kim]], [[Jacqueline Moore|Jacqueline]], [[Karen Jarrett]], [[Lauren Brooke (interviewer)|Lauren]], [[ODB (wrestler)|ODB]], [[Cheerleader Melissa|Raisha Saeed]], [[Trenesha Biggers|Rhaka Khan]], [[Nicole Raczynski|Roxxi]], [[Shelly Martinez|Salinas]], [[Sharmell Sullivan|Sharmell]], [[SoCal Val]], [[Traci Brooks]], [[Taylor Wilde]], and [[Velvet Sky]] documenting the 1st year anniversary of the launching of the division. Karen Jarrett was chosen for the cover, with an alternative cover featuring Christy Hemme.<ref>https://www.amazon.com/gp/customer-media/product-gallery/B001CCY448?index=0</ref>
The popularity of women in Impact Wrestling has also resulted in the company devoting pay-per-view to television specials to the women's division. At the end of the year of 2009 on December 31, TNA promoted a special four-hour, all Knockout episode of ''Impact!'', titled ''New Year's Knockout Eve'', which featured a tournament for the number one contendership to the Women's Knockout Championship. [[April Hunter]] who competed with the organization in its early years returned in this special competing in a tag team match.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://pwtorch.com/artman2/publish/TV_Reports_9/article_37772.shtml|title=Parks' TNA New Year's Knockout Eve Report 12/31: Ongoing "virtual time" coverage of the special, including TNA Knockouts Tournament|last=Parks|first=Greg|date=2009-12-31|work=PWTorch|accessdate=2010-10-01}}</ref> Six years later, TNA announced the second Knockouts-themed show for the first time which aired on April 17, 2015 titled 'TKO: Total Knockouts'.<ref>http://www.diva-dirt.com/108392/tna-announces-all-knockouts-episode-of-impact/</ref>
In the year of 2010, TNA premiered an all Knockout highlight pay-per-view special on October 1, titled TNA Knockouts: Mad Sexy Volume 1, featuring the best matches in the history of the Knockout division.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tnawrestling.com/news/item/2177-tna-knockouts-ppv-coming-oct-1|title=Now On PPV: Knockouts Mad Sexy Vol. 1|date=2010-10-01|accessdate=2010-10-01|work=[[Total Nonstop Action Wrestling]]}}</ref> as Volume 2 premiered February 1, 2011.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tnawrestling.com/news/item/2177-PPV-TNA-Knockouts-Mad-Sexy-Volume-2|title=PPV: TNA Knockouts Mad Sexy Volume 2|accessdate=2011-01-29|work=[[Total Nonstop Action Wrestling]]}}</ref> Three years later, TNA recorded an all knockouts pay-per-view on March 7, which aired on September 6th, titled '''''[[TNA One Night Only#Knockouts Knockdown|TNA Knockouts Knockdown]]'''''. It was part of special series of pay-per-views released by TNA called '''''[[TNA One Night Only]]'''''. Since the start of the first event, [[Trinity (wrestler)|Trinity]], [[Jacqueline Moore|Jacqueline]], [[Cheerleader Melissa|Alissa Flash]], [[Josette Bynum|Sojournor Bolt]], [[Betsy Ruth|MaryKate]], [[Thea Trinidad]], and [[Shelly Martinez]] made special appearances for the company's annual event.
===TNA Knockouts Trading Cards=== [[TRISTAR Productions]] released a TNA Knockouts trading card series on April 28, 2009. The set featured [[Angelina Love]], [[Kia Stevens|Awesome Kong]], [[Christy Hemme]], [[Dixie Carter (wrestling)|Dixie Carter]], [[Daffney|The Governor]], [[Jacqueline Moore|Jacqueline]], [[Jenna Morasca]], [[Lauren Brooke (interviewer)|Lauren]], [[Madison Rayne]], [[ODB (wrestler)|ODB]], [[Cheerleader Melissa|Raisha Saeed]], [[Trenesha Biggers|Rhaka Khan]], [[Nicole Raczynski|Roxxi]], [[Sharmell Sullivan|Sharmell]], [[SoCal Val]], [[Josette Bynum|Sojournor Bolt]], [[Traci Brooks]], [[Taylor Wilde]], and [[Velvet Sky]]. Also included are cards pairing the Knockouts with male TNA wrestlers.<ref name="TNACards">{{cite web|url=http://www.tristarproductions.com/TNA/Knockouts.html|title=TNA Knockouts Trading Cards|accessdate=2009-04-12|publisher=TRISTAR Productions.com}}</ref>
===Playboy=== Shortly before leaving Impact Wrestling, backstage interviewer [[Leticia Cline]] appeared on the cover of the November/December 2007 issue of ''[[Playboy Special Edition#Sexy Girls Next Door|Playboy's Sexy Girls Next Door]]'', which included her nude photo shoot.
In an interview with ''[[The Sun (United Kingdom)|The Sun]]'', [[Traci Brooks]] confirmed that ''[[Playboy]]'' magazine (which previously had a partnership agreement with WWE prior to the organization converting to PG-rated television content) reached a new partnership agreement with Impact Wrestling. Brooks was originally scheduled to be featured in the November 2009 issue including becoming the first Impact Wrestling Knockout to appear in ''Playboy''.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.thesun.co.uk/sol/homepage/sport/wrestling/2556779/Traci-Brooks-to-pose-nude-in-Playboy-TNA-Wrestling.html|title=Traci Brooks poses nude in Playboy|accessdate=2009-07-28|publisher=thesun.co.uk|location=London|first=Mike|last=Aldren|date=2009-07-27}}</ref> However, on September 2, 2009 it was reported that Playboy decided not to publish Brooks' photo shoot in their magazine.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.wrestleview.com/news2009/1251866597.php|title=Traci Brooks pulled from Playboy|work=WrestleView|accessdate=2009-09-03}}</ref> The photo shoot was instead released online through their Cyber Club website on September 17, 2009.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tnawrestling.com/content/view/1705/84/|title=Knockout Traci Brooks Poses For Playboy|date=2009-09-11|accessdate=2009-09-11|publisher=[[Total Nonstop Action Wrestling]]|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091114051537/http://www.tnawrestling.com/content/view/1705/84/|archivedate=November 14, 2009}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wrestleview.com/news2009/1252784515.php?style=dark|title=Release date for Traci in Playboy|publisher=Wrestleview.com|first=Adam|last=Martin|date=2009-09-12|accessdate=2009-09-12}}</ref>
===Other===
====Publications==== [[The Beautiful People (professional wrestling)|Beautiful People]] members [[Angelina Love]] and [[Velvet Sky]] were featured on the cover and in a pictorial in the December 2009 issue of ''[[Muscle & Fitness]]'' magazine, which also included photos of [[Lauren Brooke (interviewer)|Lauren Brooke]] and [[SoCal Val]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tnawrestling.com/content/view/1742/84/|title=On Sale: Knockouts In Muscle & Fitness|accessdate=2009-10-16|publisher=TNAwrestling.com|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091010231240/http://www.tnawrestling.com/content/view/1742/84/|archivedate=October 10, 2009}}</ref> Velvet Sky was named "Woman of the Year" by ''Modelsmania'' magazine after featuring on the cover and in a pictorial in the August 2013 issue of the publication.<ref>[http://dailywrestlingnews.com/new-alliance-name-revealed-velvet-sky-covers-models-mania-magazine/ Velvet Sky cover Modelsmania Magazine] dailywrestlingnews.com. 11-08-2013. Retrieved 02-12-2013.</ref><ref>[http://dailywrestlingnews.com/photo-velvet-sky-named-woman-of-the-year/Velvet Sky named Woman of the Year by Modelsmania Magazine] dailywrestlingnews.com. 10-09-2013. Retrieved 02-12-2013.</ref> Earlier that year Sky was reunited with former teammate Angelina Love when they featured together on the cover and in a pictorial in the January/February 2013 issue of ''Modelsmania'' magazine.<ref>[http://kocosports.net/2012/11/27/wrestling/angelina-love-and-velvet-sky-featured-on-the-cover-of-the-latest-edition-of-models-mania-magazine/ Love and Sky - January/February 2013 issue of Modelsmania Magazine] kocosports.net 27.11.2012. Retrieved 02-12-2013.</ref>
====Media==== In 2009, [[Shantelle Taylor|Taylor Wilde]] and [[The Beautiful People (professional wrestling)|The Beautiful People]] ([[Angelina Love]] and [[Velvet Sky]]) appeared in the U.S. reality show ''[[Made (TV series)|MTV Made]]'' to compete in a match involving a teen trained by [[A.J. Styles]].
Some of the current and former Impact Knockouts have had short television and movie careers outside of Impact Wrestling. Former backstage interviewer [[Lauren Brooke (interviewer)|Lauren Brooke]] hosts ''Top Ten'' and ''Destination Golf'' on the [[Golf Channel]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.theofficiallaurenbrooke.com/resume.html|title=Lauren Brook: Resume|accessdate=2009-10-16|publisher=TheUnofficialLaurenBrooke.com}}</ref> [[SoCal Val]] appeared in a television commercial for Morphoplex.<ref name=prime>{{cite web|url=http://slam.canoe.ca/Slam/Wrestling/2006/01/03/1377304.html|title=So Cal Val: Setting a prime example|author=Sawicki, Jonathon|publisher=SLAM! Wrestling|accessdate=2008-12-12|date=January 24, 2006}}</ref> [[Christy Hemme]] had roles in ''[[Bloodstained Memoirs]]'', ''Fallen Angels'', and ''Bubba's Chili Parlor''. Hemme has also pursued a singing career and released songs on [[MySpace]] and [[iTunes]].<ref>[http://www.myspace.com/sexandviolencemovie Bloodstained Memoirs Website]</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/name/nm1452434/|title=Internet Movie Database: Christy Hemme|accessdate=2009-10-16|publisher=IMDB.com}}</ref> [[Traci Brooks]] had a role in ''Zombie Beach Party''.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/name/nm1816992/|title=Internet Movie Database: Tracy Brookshaw|accessdate=2009-10-16|publisher=IMDB.com}}</ref> [[Cheerleader Melissa|Alissa Flash]] has a role in the 2010 documentary ''False Finish''.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0027177/|title=Internet Movie Database: Melissa Anderson (I)|accessdate=2009-10-16|publisher=IMDB.com}}</ref> Former backstage interviewer [[Leticia Cline]] appeared in the fifth season of the reality series ''[[Beauty and the Geek]]'' in 2008, as well as the [[Howard Stern]] reality series ''Bowling Beauties''.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/name/nm2684814/|title=Internet Movie Database: Leticia Cline|accessdate=2009-10-16|publisher=IMDB.com}}</ref> [[Angelina Love]] had a role in the 2008 [[Independent film|indie]] film titled ''Good Intentions'' starring country music star [[LeAnn Rimes]] and [[Luke Perry]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/name/nm2672733/|title=Internet Movie Database: Angel Williams (II)|accessdate=2009-10-16|publisher=IMDB.com}}</ref> In 2012, [[Lisa Marie Varon|Tara]] appeared in the U.S. reality show ''[[Made (TV series)|MTV Made]]'' coaching an aspiring teen trying to be a professional wrestler while [[Brooke Tessmacher]] and [[Velvet Sky]] also former Knockout [[Angelina Love]] appeared in the episode. In June 2012, Velvet Sky had the lead role in [[Montgomery Gentry]]'s music video for their song "[[Rebels on the Run#Track listing|So Called Life]]".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pwtorch.com/artman2/publish/quicknews/article_62680.shtml|title=New item announced for live Impact|date=2012-06-21|last=Caldwell|first=James|accessdate=2012-06-22|work=Pro Wrestling Torch}}</ref> In July 2012, [[Mickie James]] featured in [[Bucky Covington]]'s music video for his song "[[Good Guys (album)|Drinking Side of Country]]".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://mickiejames.groundctrl.net/news/88981|title=Mickie James in new country music video|date=July 24, 2012|accessdate=July 24, 2012|work=mickiejames.com}}</ref> In June 2013, Mickie James starred in a [[Dr Pepper]] advert, which was part of the company's new advertising program. It featured "one of a kind" individuals talking about the role of Dr Pepper in their lives.<ref>[http://www.diva-dirt.com/2013/06/10/in-video-mickie-james-stars-in-new-dr-pepper-promo/ Mickie James in new Dr Pepper Promo] diva-dirt.com. 10-06-2013. Retrieved 02-12-2013.</ref>

===Miss TNA=== The first Miss TNA was crowned on June 26, 2002, when [[Cathy Dingman|Taylor Vaughn]] won a 9-woman lingerie battle royal. The title was abandoned in November 2002.
{| class="wikitable" !style="background: #e3e3e3;" width=20%|'''Wrestler:''' !style="background: #e3e3e3;" width=3%|'''Reigns:''' !style="background: #e3e3e3;" width=17%|'''Date:''' !style="background: #e3e3e3;" width=20%|'''Place:''' !style="background: #e3e3e3;" width=40%|'''Notes:''' |- |[[Cathy Dingman|Taylor Vaughn]] |1 |June 26, 2002 |Huntsville, AL |Defeats [[Mickie James|Alexis Laree]], [[Elektra (wrestling)|Elektra]], Erin Bray, [[Francine Fournier|Francine]], Miss Joni, Sasha, [[Daffney|Shannon]], and Teresa Tyler in a "Lingerie Battle Royal" |- |[[Allan Funk|Bruce]] |1 |July 31, 2002 |Nashville, TN | |- |April Pennington |1 |November 27, 2002 |Nashville, TN |Pennington was given the crown by Bruce and the title was immediately abandoned |- |Title Abandoned | |November 27, 2002 | | |}
===Babe/Knockout of the Year=== The TNA Babe/Knockout of the Year contest was a contest where fans vote on TNA Wrestling's official website for who their favorite TNA Knockout for that year, the winners were announced during the [[Total Nonstop Action Wrestling Year End Awards|Year End Awards]] on ''[[TNA iMPACT!]]''. The award was established in 2003 and ended in 2007.
{|class="wikitable" !Wrestler !Year inducted |- |[[Stephanie Trinity|Trinity]] |2003 |- |[[Traci Brooks]] |2004 |- |[[Jackie Gayda]] |2005 |- |[[Christy Hemme]] |2006 |- |[[Gail Kim]] |2007 |}
===Queen of the Knockouts (2013–2016)=== TNA held a series of matches featuring various Knockouts at [[TNA One Night Only#Knockout Knockdown\|TNA One Night Only: Knockout Knockdown]]. The winners of these matches would advance to a battle royal, with the winner being crowned the "Queen of the Knockouts". It took place on March 17, 2013 from the Impact Wrestling Zone in Orlando, Florida and aired on PPV on September 6, 2013. No queen was crowned in 2017.
{| class="wikitable" |- !style="background: #e3e3e3;"|No. !style="background: #e3e3e3;"|Results<ref>{{cite web|url=http://bleacherreport.com/articles/1570997-tna-knockout-knockdown-2013-spoilers-complete-results-and-analysis|title=TNA Knockout Knockdown 2013 Spoilers: Complete Results and Analysis|last=Zucker|first=Joseph|date=2013-03-17|publisher=[[Bleacher Report]]|accessdate=2013-04-30}}</ref> !style="background: #e3e3e3;"|Event, Date and Location |- |align=center| I ||[[Gail Kim]] defeated [[The Blossom Twins|Hannah Blossom]], [[Jacqueline Moore|Jackie Moore]], [[Lei'D Tapa]], [[Mickie James]], [[Velvet Sky]], [[Brooke Tessmacher|Miss Tessmacher]], [[ODB (wrestler)|ODB]], and [[Lisa Marie Varon|Tara]]||[[TNA One Night Only#Knockouts Knockdown|Knockouts Knockdown]]<br/>March 17, 2013,<br/>[[Orlando, Florida]] |- |align=center| II ||[[Madison Rayne]] defeated [[Angelina Love]], Gail Kim, Brooke Tessmacher, [[Marti Bell]], [[Taryn Terrell]], [[Reby Sky]], and [[Jade (wrestler)|Mia Yim]]||[[TNA One Night Only#Knockouts Knockdown 2|Knockouts Knockdown 2]]<br/>May 10, 2014<br/>[[Orlando, Florida]] |- |align=center| III ||[[Kia Stevens|Awesome Kong]] defeated [[Thea Trinidad]], Gail Kim, [[Jessicka Havok|Havok]], Taryn Terrell, Brooke Tessmacher, and Madison Rayne ||[[TNA One Night Only#Knockouts Knockdown 3|Knockouts Knockdown 3]]<br/>February 14, 2015<br/>[[Orlando, Florida]] |- |align=center| 4 ||Jade defeated Madison Rayne, [[Allysin Kay]], [[Cherry Bomb (wrestler)|Laura Dennis]], [[Courtney Rush|Rosemary]], [[Barbi Hayden]], Marti Bell, and [[Rebel (wrestler)|Rebel]] ||[[TNA One Night Only#Knockouts Knockdown 4|Knockouts Knockdown 4]]<br/>March 17, 2016<br/>[[Orlando, Florida]] |- |}
===Queen of the Cage=== The Queen of the Cage match was a professional wrestling match exclusive to TNA. The match was determined annually at the [[TNA Lockdown|Lockdown]] pay-per-view event. In 2008, the match began as a [[Battle royal (professional wrestling)#Reverse battle royal|reverse-battle royal]] involving eight wrestlers. The first two wrestlers that entered the cage then competed in a one-on-one match that was won via pin fall or submission. The winner became the number one contender for the TNA Women's Knockout Championship. In 2009, the match was a [[Professional wrestling match types#Basic non-elimination matches|traditional four-way match]]. The match type has since been dropped. {| class="wikitable" !style="background: #e3e3e3;"|No. !style="background: #e3e3e3;"|Match !style="background: #e3e3e3;"|Event, Date and Location |- |align=center| I || [[Nicole Raczynski|Roxxi Laveaux]] defeated [[Angelina Love]], [[Christy Hemme]], [[Jacqueline Moore|Jacqueline]], [[Trenesha Biggers|Rhaka Khan]], [[Shelly Martinez|Salinas]], [[Traci Brooks]], and [[Velvet Sky]] || [[Lockdown (2008)|Lockdown 2008]]<br/>April 13, 2008,<br/>[[Lowell, Massachusetts]] |- |align=center| II || [[ODB (wrestler)|ODB]] defeated [[Daffney]], [[Madison Rayne]], and [[Josette Bynum|Sojournor Bolt]] || [[Lockdown (2009)|Lockdown 2009]]<br/>April 19, 2009,<br/>[[Philadelphia|Philadelphia, Pennsylvania]] |}

{{Refimprove|date=September 2009}} [[Image:TAInterlingua Figura1.png|thumb|300px|Figure 1. Demonstration of the languages which are used in the process of translating using a ''bridge'' language.]] '''Interlingual machine translation''' is one of the classic approaches to [[machine translation]]. In this approach, the source language, i.e. the text to be translated is transformed into an interlingua, i.e., an abstract language-independent representation. The target language is then generated from the interlingua. Within the rule-based machine translation paradigm, the interlingual approach is an alternative to the [[dictionary-based machine translation|direct approach]] and the [[transfer-based machine translation|transfer approach]].
In the direct approach, words are translated directly without passing through an additional representation. In the transfer approach the source language is transformed into an abstract, less language-specific representation. Linguistic rules which are specific to the language pair then transform the source language representation into an abstract target language representation and from this the target sentence is generated.
The interlingual approach to machine translation has advantages and disadvantages. The advantages are that it requires fewer components in order to relate each source language to each target language, it takes fewer components to add a new language, it supports paraphrases of the input in the original language, it allows both the analysers and generators to be written by monolingual system developers, and it handles languages that are very different from each other (e.g. English and Arabic<ref>Abdel Monem, A., Shaalan, K., Rafea, A., Baraka, H., [http://www.springerlink.com/content/76t73q5805743640/ Generating Arabic Text in Multilingual Speech-to-Speech Machine Translation Framework], Machine Translation, Springer, Netherlands, 20(4): 205-258, December 2008.</ref>). The obvious disadvantage is that the definition of an interlingua is difficult and maybe even impossible for a wider domain. The ideal context for interlingual machine translation is thus multilingual machine translation in a very specific domain.
==History== The first ideas about interlingual machine translation appeared in the 17th century with [[Descartes]] and [[Gottfried Wilhelm Leibniz|Leibniz]], who came up with theories of how to create dictionaries using universal numerical codes. Others, such as [[Cave Beck]], [[Athanasius Kircher]] and [[Johann Joachim Becher]] worked on developing an unambiguous universal language based on the principles of [[logic]] and iconographs. In 1668, [[John Wilkins]] described his interlingua in his "Essay towards a Real Character and a Philosophical Language". In the 18th and 19th centuries many proposals for "universal" international languages were developed, the most well known being [[Esperanto]].
That said, applying the idea of a universal language to machine translation did not appear in any of the first significant approaches. Instead, work started on pairs of languages. However, during the 1950s and 60s, researchers in [[Cambridge]] headed by [[Margaret Masterman]], in [[Leningrad]] headed by [[Nikolai Andreev]] and in [[Milan]] by [[Silvio Ceccato]] started work in this area. The idea was discussed extensively by the Israeli philosopher [[Yehoshua Bar-Hillel]] in 1969.
During the 1970s, noteworthy research was done in [[Grenoble]] by researchers attempting to translate physics and mathematical texts from [[Russian language|Russian]] to [[French language|French]], and in [[Texas]] a similar project (METAL) was ongoing for Russian to [[English language|English]]. Early interlingual MT systems were also built at [[Stanford]] in the 1970s by [[Roger Schank]] and [[Yorick Wilks]]; the former became the basis of a commercial system for the transfer of funds, and the latter's code is preserved at [[The Computer Museum, Boston|The Computer Museum]] at [[Boston]] as the first interlingual machine translation system.
In the 1980s, renewed relevance was given to interlingua-based, and knowledge-based approaches to machine translation in general, with much research going on in the field. The uniting factor in this research was that high-quality translation required abandoning the idea of requiring total comprehension of the text. Instead, the translation should be based on linguistic knowledge and the specific domain in which the system would be used. The most important research of this era was done in [[distributed language translation]] (DLT) in [[Utrecht (city)|Utrecht]], which worked with a modified version of [[Esperanto]], and the Fujitsu system in Japan.
==Outline== [[Image:TAInterlingua Figura2.png|thumb|300px|Figure 2. a) Translation graph required for direct or [[transfer-based machine translation]] (12 dictionaries are required); b) Translation graph required when using a bridge language (only 8 translation modules are required).]]
In this method of translation, the interlingua can be thought of as a way of describing the analysis of a text written in a '''source language''' such that it is possible to convert its morphological, syntactic, semantic (and even pragmatic) characteristics, that is "meaning" into a '''target language'''. This interlingua is able to describe all of the characteristics of all of the languages which are to be translated, instead of simply translating from one language to another.
[[Image:TAInterlingua Figura3.png|thumb|300px|Figure 3: Translation graph using two interlinguas.]]
Sometimes two interlinguas are used in translation. It is possible that one of the two covers more of the characteristics of the source language, and the other possess more of the characteristics of the target language. The translation then proceeds by converting sentences from the first language into sentences closer to the target language through two stages. The system may also be set up such that the second interlingua uses a more specific vocabulary that is closer, or more aligned with the target language, and this could improve the translation quality.
The above-mentioned system is based on the idea of using linguistic proximity to improve the translation quality from a text in one original language to many other structurally similar languages from only one original analysis. This principle is also used in [[Pivot language|pivot machine translation]], where a [[natural language]] is used as a "bridge" between two more distant languages. For example, in the case of translating to [[English language|English]] from [[Ukrainian language|Ukrainian]] using [[Russian language|Russian]] as an intermediate language.<ref>Bogdan Babych, Anthony Hartley, and Serge Sharoff (2007) "[http://www.mt-archive.info/MTS-2007-Babych-1.pdf Translating from under-resourced languages: comparing direct transfer against pivot translation]". ''Proceedings of MT Summit XI, 10–14 September 2007, Copenhagen, Denmark''. pp.29--35</ref>
==Translation process== In interlingual machine translation systems, there are two monolingual components: the ''analysis'' of the source language and the interlingual, and the ''generation'' of the interlingua and the target language. It is however necessary to distinguish between interlingual systems using only syntactic methods (for example the systems developed in the 1970s at the universities of Grenoble and Texas) and those based on [[artificial intelligence]] (from 1987 in Japan and the research at the universities of Southern California and Carnegie Mellon). The first type of system corresponds to that outlined in Figure 1. while the other types would be approximated by the diagram in Figure 4.
The following resources are necessary to an interlingual machine translation system: [[Image:TAInterlingua Figura4.png|thumb|300px|right|Figure 4. Machine translation in a knowledge-based system.]] * Dictionaries (or lexicons) for analysis and generation (specific to the [[definition domain|domain]] and the languages involved). * A conceptual lexicon (specific to the domain), which is the [[knowledge base]] about events and entities known in the domain. * A set of projection rules (specific to the domain and the languages). * Grammars for the analysis and generation of the languages involved.
One of the problems of knowledge-based machine translation systems is that it becomes impossible to create databases for domains larger than very specific areas. Another is that processing these databases is very computationally expensive.
==Efficacy== One of the main advantages of this strategy is that it provides an economical way to make multilingual translation systems. With an interlingua it becomes unnecessary to make a translation pair between each pair of languages in the system. So instead of creating <math>n(n-1)</math> language pairs, where <math>n</math> is the number of languages in the system, it is only necessary to make <math>2n</math> pairs between the <math>n</math> languages and the interlingua.
The main disadvantage of this strategy is the difficulty of creating an adequate interlingua. It should be both abstract and independent of the source and target languages. The more languages added to the translation system, and the more different they are, the more potent the interlingua must be to express all possible translation directions. Another problem is that it is difficult to extract meaning from texts in the original languages to create the intermediate representation.
==Existing interlingual machine translation systems==
* [https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007%2FBF00936424#page-1 Calliope-Aero] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20131127193918/http://linguasys.com/carabao#interlingua Carabao Linguistic Virtual Machine] * [http://www.grammaticalframework.org Grammatical Framework] * [http://prutzkow.com/en-us/numbers/ Number Translator]
==See also== * [[Intermediate representation]] * [[Pivot language]] * [[Universal Networking Language]] * [[Knowledge representation and reasoning]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=April 2012}} [[File:Fondeville.png|thumb|1667 edition of ''la Pastorala deu Paisan'']] '''Jean-Henri Fondeville''' ([[Béarnese dialect|Béarnese Occitan]]: ''Joan Enric de Fondevila''; {{circa}} 1638 – 22 October 1705) was a [[Béarnese dialect|Béarnese Occitan]] writer.
Fondeville is author of the ''la Pastorala deu Paisan'' and also of the vehemently anti-Calvinist pastoral poem ''Eglògas''.
== Biography == Fondeville was born after the integration of [[Béarn]] into the [[Kingdom of France]] in 1621.
Before this event, Béarn had been part of the [[Kingdom of Navarre]]. When Queen [[Jeanne d'Albret]] adopted [[Calvinism]], the kingdom became Protestant, keeping Béarnese Occitan as its administrative language, and when Jeanne d'Albret's son, Henry III of Navarre, became [[Henry IV of France]] and Navarre, he maintained the kingdom's independence; however, his son, [[Louis XIII of France]], decided to merge the kingdom with France, and to re-establish Catholicism.
During this process, Fondeville's father, a Protestant priest, was offered a lifetime annuity in order to choose Catholicism. Fondeville's godfather was Jean-Henri de Salette, bishop of [[Lescar]], (in which city he Fondeville is buried under the Latin inscription ''patronus et poeta facundus'').
In addition to being a writer, Fondeville also had an illustrious career as a lawyer at the [[Parliament of Navarre and Béarn]], which had its seat in [[Pau, Pyrénées-Atlantiques|Pau]].
== Bibliography == * Fondeville, Jean-Henri. ''La Pastourale deu paysaa, qui cèrque mestièè à son hil, chéns nè trouba à son grat. Pèsse divértissente et connégude én Béarn, ainsi què d'autès oubratgès déü médich authou, en quoato actes''. [[Pau, Pyrénées-Atlantiques|Pau]] : Vignancour, 1767. * Fondeville, Jean-Henri. ''La pastourale deu paysaa qui cerque mestièe a soun hilh, chens ne trouba a soun grat, en quoate actes''. Pau : Ribaut, 1885.
== Online editions == *Sus gallica.bnf.fr **[http://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/bpt6k5745759c.r=fondeville.langFR Edicion de 1885] ** [http://numerique.bibliotheque.toulouse.fr/cgi-bin/superlibrary?a=d&d=/ark:/74899/B315556101_RD18_0759 Edicion de 1767]
