revision.text:
[[Luganda]], the main language of southern Uganda, is a [[tonal language]] of the [[Bantu languages|Bantu]] family, traditionally described as having three tones: high (''{{IPA|á}}''), low (''{{IPA|à}}'') and falling (''{{IPA|â}}''). Rising tones are not found in Luganda, even on long vowels, since a sequence such as [''àá''] automatically becomes [''áá''].<ref name="Luganda Basic Course, p.xiii">''Luganda Basic Course'', p. xiii.</ref><ref>Hyman & Katamba (1993), p. 56.</ref>
Tones perform various functions in Luganda: they help to distinguish one word from another, they distinguish one verb tense from another, and they are also used in sentence intonation, for example, to distinguish a statement from a question.
In general in Luganda some words are accented, with the accent shown by a fall in pitch from high to low: ''ens'''î''''' 'country', ''ekib'''ú'''ga'' 'city'. Others words, such as ''ekitabo'' 'book', are unaccented. In most circumstances accentless words receive an automatic default tone, called a phrasal tone, on all syllables except the first: ''ekítábó''; but in some circumstances this default tone does not appear, for example, when the word is the subject of a sentence or qualified by a number. Default tones are also added (or not added) at the end of accented words immediately following the fall in pitch, e.g. ''eddw'''â'''liro'' or ''eddw'''â'''líró'' 'hospital', ''mas'''é'''rengeta'' or ''mas'''é'''rengétá'' 'south'.
The description is made more complicated, however, by certain exceptions. For example, in some verbal forms the default tones begin not as expected immediately after the accent but after an interval of two or three low-toned syllables, e.g. ''b'''á'''lilabá'' 'they will see'. These complexities prevent Luganda from being described as a simple pitch-accent language.<ref>Hyman (2009).</ref>
The complexity of the Luganda tonal system has attracted the attention of numerous scholars, who have sought ways of describing Luganda tones most economically according to different linguistic models.<ref>See Hyman & Katamba (1993) for an overview.</ref>
==General characteristics== Although there are many complexities of detail, the general lines of tone in Luganda are simple. Most sentences have a gradual descent from the first high tone to the last, as in the following sentence:<ref name=LBC105>''Luganda Basic Course'', p. 105.</ref> *''kye kib'''<u>ú</u>'''ga ekik'''<u>ú</u>'''lu mu Ug'''<u>áń</u>'''da'' 'it is the chief city in Uganda'
The three high tones '''''ú''''', '''''ú''''', and '''''áń''''' stand out prominently from the other syllables, and each one is a little lower than the last. The toneless syllables between are lower in pitch than the high tones. This descent is known as [[downdrift]] or 'automatic downstep' and is common in many African languages whenever tones come in a sequence HLH.
Another type of tonal pattern very common in Luganda is the high tone plateau.<ref>For the term see Hyman & Katamba (1993), p. 44.</ref> In this pattern, two high tones are at the same level, and the voice remains continuously high from one the other: *''k<u>'''í'''rí mú Úg'''áń'''</u>da'' 'it is in Uganda'<ref name=LBC105 /> *''mu mamb<u>úká gá Úg'''áń'''</u>da'' 'in the north of Uganda'<ref name=LBC26>''Luganda Basic Course'', p. 26.</ref>
A third type of tonal pattern, not quite so common, is to have a series of low tones followed by a jump to a high one: *''Mbarara kib'''ú'''ga'' 'Mbarara is a city'<ref name=LBC138>''Luganda Basic Course'', p. 138.</ref> *''ebitabo kk'''ú'''mi'' 'ten books'<ref name=LBC103>''Luganda Basic Course'', p. 103.</ref>
These three tonal patterns will be heard to occur again and again in Luganda sentences, and much of the description below concerns when to use one and when another.
==Types==
There are various types of high tone in Luganda, of which lexical, grammatical and phrasal tones are the most important. (To these can be added boundary tones and other tones indicating intonation.)
===Lexical tones=== Lexical high tones are those that go with particular words, such as those on the words below: *''ekib'''ú'''ga'' 'city' *''ens'''î''''' 'country'
When a word with final tone such as ''ens'''î''''' 'country' is spoken in isolation or at the end of a sentence, the tone is always heard as a falling tone; but in other contexts, it will generally be heard as an ordinary high tone.
Falling lexical tones can also be heard in non-final position: *''eddw'''â'''l<u>író</u>'' 'hospital'
Some words in Luganda have two lexical high tones. When this happens the two tones link into a plateau; that is, the syllables between are also raised.<ref>''Luganda Pretraining Program'', p. 88.</ref> (In this article, a plateau will be shown by underlining.) *''K<u>'''á'''mpál'''â'''</u>'' '(the city of) [[Kampala]]' *''edd<u>'''ú'''úk'''â'''</u>'' 'shop'
A lexical tone, if it does not form a plateau with a following lexical tone, is always followed by a low tone. This low tone can either be in the following syllable, as in ''ekib'''ú'''ga'' 'city' or the second half (mora) of a syllable containing a falling tone, as in ''eddw'''â'''l<u>író</u>'' 'hospital' or ''ens'''î''''' 'country'.
===Grammatical tones=== A grammatical tone is one that arises when a verb is used in a particular tense. For example, a verb in the subjunctive mood always has a high or falling tone on the last syllable:<ref name="Luganda Basic Course, p.182">''Luganda Basic Course'', p. 182.</ref> *''muyingir'''ê''''' 'you should come in, please come in'
In this article, to distinguish them from phrasal high tones, lexical and grammatical tones will be marked in bold.
===Phrasal tones=== Phrasal tones are high tones which are automatically added to words in certain contexts; in other contexts the same word may be pronounced without phrasal tones. For example, when a word without lexical tones is the subject of a sentence, or followed by a number or quantity word, it remains toneless: *''Mbarara kib'''ú'''ga'' 'Mbarara is a city'<ref name=LBC138 /> *''ebitabo kk'''ú'''mi'' 'ten books'<ref name=LBC103 />
But in most other contexts, or when spoken in isolation, the word has a high tone on all the syllables except the first [[Mora (linguistics)|mora]] of the word (the phrasal tones are shown here by being underlined): *''eb<u>ítábó</u>'' 'books' *''mu mamb<u>úká</u>'' 'in the north'<ref name=LBC26 />
A geminate consonant such as [''tt''] counts as one mora, and so if a word begins with a geminate consonant, the phrasal tone can begin immediately after it: *''T<u>óró</u>'' [''tt<u>óóró</u>''] '(the kingdom of) [[Toro Kingdom|Toro]]'<ref name="Luganda Basic Course, p.29">''Luganda Basic Course'', p. 29.</ref> *''ggw<u>é</u>'' [''ggw<u>éé</u>''] 'you (sg.)' *''ss<u>óméró</u>'' 'it is a school'<ref>''Luganda Pretraining Program'', p.82.</ref>
Since a rising tone [''àá''] becomes a level high tone [''áá''] in Luganda, the following word also has a high tone throughout: *''y<u>éé</u>'' 'yes'<ref>''Luganda Basic Course'', p. 12.</ref>
Phrasal tones can also be added to the end of words that have a lexical high tone. However, between the lexical tone and the phrasal tones there must always be at least one low-toned syllable or mora: *''t'''ú'''gend<u>á</u>'' 'we are going' *''amas'''é'''reng<u>étá</u>'' 'south'
If the lexical tone is a falling one, the second half the syllable with the tone counts as a low-toned mora, and the phrasal tones begin immediately on the following syllable: *''eddw'''â'''l<u>író</u>'' 'hospital' *''abag'''â'''nd<u>á</u>'' 'Baganda people'
Whenever a word has a lexical as well as a phrasal tone like this, the lexical tone and the phrasal tone do not form a plateau but instead there is a sequence HLH. As with every sequence HLH, the second H (which is the phrasal tone) is a little lower than the first.<ref>''Luganda Pretraining Program'', p. 147.</ref>
A lexical or grammatical tone cannot form a plateau with a following phrasal tone; there is always at least one low-toned mora in between. However, a phrasal tone can very easily form a plateau with a following lexical tone or phrasal tone: *''mu kyal<u>ó Másí'''ń'''</u>di'' 'in the village of Masindi'<ref name=LBCxviii /> *''t'''ú'''gend<u>á mú lúgúúdó</u>'' 'we are going into the street'<ref name="Luganda Basic Course, p.xxiii"/> *''ay<u>ágálá ókúlímá ámátóóké</u>'' 'he wants to cultivate bananas'<ref name=LBCxxii />
More examples of this are given below, as well as exceptions where no plateau is formed.
Phrasal tones tend to be less prominent than lexical tones and often in a sentence if a word with lexical tone is substituted for one with a phrasal tone, the pitch will be higher.
===Words containing HLL or HLLL=== Normally between a lexical or grammatical high tone in Luganda and a phrasal tone, there is just one low-toned syllable or mora. However there are some words in which a high lexical or grammatical tone is followed not by one, but by two or even three low-toned syllables: *''b'''á'''lilab<u>á</u>'' 'they will see'<ref name="Hyman & Katamba 1993, p.45">Hyman & Katamba (1993), p.45.</ref> *''ab'''á'''lilaba'' 'they who will see'
The existence of such words greatly complicates the description of Luganda tones and has important implications for theoretical accounts of the language.<ref>Hyman & Katamba (1993), p. 36.</ref> These are further discussed below.
===Intonational tones=== As well as the types of tone mentioned above, there are also intonational tones such as those which distinguish a question from a statement. For example, if a toneless word asks a yes-no question, it has high tones except the last syllable, which is low. Compare these two: *''ss<u>óméró</u>'' 'it is a school'<ref>''Luganda Pretraining Program'', p. 82.</ref> *''ss<u>ómé</u>ro?'' 'is it a school?'<ref name=LBC242>''Luganda Basic Course'', p. 242.</ref>
A question like the following has a rise-and-fall on the last vowel: *''gwe gul'''í''' gw<u>é '''ń'''néngérá wál'''î'''</u>?'' 'is it the one I see there?'<ref name=LBC242 />
Another type of intonational tone is an upglide sometimes heard just before a pause mid-sentence. (It is referred to by [[Earl Stevick|Stevick]] (1968) as 'comma intonation'.)<ref name="Luganda Basic Course, p.xxiii">''Luganda Basic Course'', p. xxiii.</ref>
===Tones and emphasis=== One way in which tones are not used in Luganda, however, is for focus or emphasis. As Crabtree says, 'The tone in Luganda is level, therefore it is impossible to emphasize as in English.' Instead he lists some other ways in which words can be emphasised in Luganda, such as placing the important word first, omitting an initial vowel where it would normally be added,<ref>Hyman & Katamba (2010), p. 76.</ref> using a relative construction (e.g. 'books are what I want'), using a negative construction (e.g. 'what I want, is it not books?') and others.<ref>Crabtree (1902), p. 144-5.</ref>
==Downdrift==
===Lexical tone downdrift=== The usual pattern when two words have lexical or grammatical high tone (unless the two tones are in the same word, as in ''K'''á'''mpál'''â''''') is for the second tone to be a little lower than the first, with the syllables in between a little lower than the high tones, making a dip: *''ebib'''ú'''ga mu ns'''î''''' 'cities in the country'<ref name=LBCxviii>''Luganda Basic Course'', p. xviii.</ref> *''bonn'''á''' bawal'''â''''' 'all of them are girls'<ref name=LBC103 /> *''at'''é'''ma omut'''î''''' 'he cuts the tree'<ref name="Luganda Basic Course, p.xi">''Luganda Basic Course'', p. xi.</ref> *''mu kib'''ú'''ga K<u>ámpál'''â'''</u>'' 'in the city of Kampala'<ref name=LBCxviii /> *''ebib'''ú'''ga bir'''í''''' 'those cities'<ref name=LBCxviii />
There is also usually a downstep if the first word ends in a lexical tone and the second word begins with one: *''balug'''ú''' m'''úń'''gi'' 'many yams'<ref name=LBCxxii>''Luganda Basic Course'', p. xxii.</ref>
The falling tone in ''balug'''û''''' 'yams' changes to a high tone in this context, but there is still a downstep just as if the L part of the HL was still audible.
There is always downdrift when a phrasal tone follows a lexical one: *''k'''í'''ri mu Buny<u>óró</u>'' 'it is in Bunyoro'<ref name="Luganda Basic Course, p.29"/>
===Phrasal tone downdrift=== A phrasal tone is usually followed by a plateau, which continues either to the next high tone or, if there is no high tone, to the end of the phrase. Nonetheless, there are some kinds of phrases where the phrasal tones continue only as far as the end of the word, after which there is a low tone. The following high tone will be lower than the phrasal tone (i.e. there will be downdrift).
An example of these types of phrases is when a noun is followed by the pronominal words ''ban<u>ó</u>'' 'these', ''ab<u>ó</u>'' 'the aforesaid', ''bonn'''â''''' 'all', or ''yekk'''â''''' 'alone' (or their equivalents in other noun classes), e.g.<ref name=LBCxx>''Luganda Basic Course'', p. xx.</ref> *''ab<u>ántú</u> ban<u>ó</u>'' 'these people' *''ab<u>ántú</u> ab<u>ó</u>'' 'the aforementioned people' *''ab<u>ántú</u> bonn'''â''''' 'all people' *''om<u>úntú</u> yekk'''â''''' 'the person alone' *''am<u>átóóké</u> an<u>ó</u> bonn'''â''''' 'all those bananas'
However, there is plateauing before demonstrative adjectives of the ''-l'''i''''' type: *''ab<u>ántú bál'''î'''</u>'' 'those people'<ref name=LBCxviii />
Two other contexts where there is downdrift after a phrasal tone word are before ''nga'' 'when, if, as' and before ''nti'' meaning 'that':<ref name=LBCxx /><ref>See also Hyman & Katamba (2010), p. 94, 96.</ref> *''b'''áá'''numy<u>á</u> nga b'''á'''lya'' 'they talked as they were eating' *''ag<u>ámbá</u> nti'' 'he says that...'
(The word ''nga'' in this context is toneless, but before a noun it has a tone: ''ng'''á''' sukk'''á'''ali'' 'like sugar'.<ref name="LBCxvii"/> It also has a tone when it means 'how...!': ''ng'''á''' wano bulú'''ń'''gi!'' 'how beautiful it is here!'<ref name=LBC242 />)
There is a similar downstep after a personal pronoun in phrases like the following: *''nz<u>é</u> Muk<u>ásá</u>'' 'I am Mukasa'<ref>''Luganda Basic Course'', p. 73.</ref> *''ggw<u>é</u> an'''í'''?'' [''ggwáaní''] 'who are you?'<ref>''Luganda Basic Course'', p. 3.</ref>
==Plateauing==
===Lexical tone plateauing=== As noted above, the usual pattern with words containing lexical tones is for each word in a series to be a little lower in pitch than the one before. However, there are some circumstances when two lexical tones will be on the same level and make a plateau.<ref>Hyman & Katamba (1993), p. 44.</ref>
====Phrases with 'of'==== Typical of such phrases are those containing the word -'''''á''''' 'of', which forms a plateau not only with the preceding high tone but also with the following one, for example: *''mu mas<u>'''é'''réngétá g'''á''' Úg'''áń'''</u>da'' 'in the south of Uganda'<ref name=LBC26 />
The plateau is shown here by underlining.
If the second word is toneless, however, a plateau is made only with the preceding word: *''ekkeng<u>'''é'''lé y'''ó'''</u>mul<u>énzí</u>'' 'the boy's bell' (shortened from ''y'''á''' om<u>úlénzí</u>'')<ref name=LBCxx />
====Verb + Location==== Another kind of phrase which often has plateauing is 'verb + location', for example: *''k<u>'''í'''rí mú Búg'''áń'''</u>da'' 'it is in Buganda'<ref name=LBC105 /> *''b<u>'''á'''géńdá W'''áń'''</u>degey<u>á</u>'' 'they are going to Wandegeya''<ref name="Luganda Basic Course, p.xix">''Luganda Basic Course'', p. xix.</ref> *''nab<u>'''í'''gúl'''á''' mú K'''á'''mpál'''â'''</u>'' 'I bought them in Kampala'<ref name="Luganda Basic Course, p.167">''Luganda Basic Course'', p. 167.</ref> *''ogit<u>'''é'''éká kú mmé'''é'''</u>za'' 'you put (Present tense) it on the table'<ref name="Luganda Basic Course, p.168">''Luganda Basic Course'', p. 168.</ref> *''wano w<u>'''á'''yítíbwá Kíb'''ú'''</u>li'' 'this place is called Kibuli'<ref name=LBC242 />
Sometimes there can be a slight dip in this kind of phrase, e.g. *''k'''í'''ri mu mas<u>'''é'''réngétá g'''á''' Úg'''áń'''</u>da'' 'it is in the south of Uganda'<ref name=LBC26 />
But even here the three underlying high tones are on the same pitch and do not drift downwards.
However, there is usually no plateauing in this type of phrase when the verb is relative: *''ek'''í'''ri mu Bug'''áń'''da'' 'which is in Buganda' (with downdrift)<ref name="Luganda Basic Course, p.219">''Luganda Basic Course'', p. 219.</ref>
There is also no plateauing when the verb is negative: *''teb'''á'''v'''á''' mu Ug'''áń'''da'' 'they don't come from Uganda'<ref name="Luganda Basic Course, p.167"/>
There can also be no plateauing between an earlier lexical tone and a following phrasal tone: *''k'''í'''ri mu Buny<u>óró</u>'' 'it is in Bunyoro'<ref name="Luganda Basic Course, p.29"/>
====Verb + focussed object==== A plateau is also possible between verb and object, when the object is emphasised or focussed. Contrast:<ref>Hyman (2017), p. 171.</ref> *''b'''á'''gul<u>á ébík'''ó'''</u>po'' 'they buy cups' *''b<u>'''á'''gúlá bík'''ó'''</u>po'' 'they buy <small>CUPS</small>' (not something else)
===='And'==== Another situation where plateauing will follow a lexical tone is after the word ''né'' 'and', which has a tone when used before a noun: *''Ug'''áń'''da n<u>'''é''' K'''é'''</u>nya'' (pronounced ''yug'''áń'''da n<u>'''é''' kk'''é'''</u>nya'') 'Uganda and Kenya'<ref>''Luganda Basic Course'', p. 166.</ref> *''eb<u>íjánjááló n' '''é'''bíny'''ó'''</u>obw<u>á</u>'' 'the beans and the peanuts'<ref name=LBCxviii /> *''n' <u>'''á'''báwál'''â'''</u>'' 'and girls'<ref>''Luganda Basic Course'', p. 118.</ref>
But there is no plateau between the tone of ''n'''é''''' and a following phrasal tone: *''ebiny'''ó'''obwa n' '''é'''bij<u>ánjááló</u>'' 'the peanuts and the beans'<ref name=LBCxviii />
According to Hyman (2017), the word ''na/ne'' itself is underlyingly toneless, and the tone comes from the augment of the noun (i.e. the initial ''e-'' or ''a-'' or ''o-''), which in an earlier stage of the language was high-toned.<ref name="Hyman 2017, p. 170">Hyman (2017), p. 170.</ref>
''Ne'' is in fact toneless in phrases like the following, when it is followed by a 'narrative tense' verb (a 'narrative tense' verb is a form of relative clause verb without its initial vowel, used after ''ne''): *''ne b<u>'''á'''lím'''â'''</u>'' 'and they cultivate'<ref>''Luganda Basic Course'', p. 232.</ref>
The word ''n'''á''''', meaning 'with', is also contained in the word ''b<u>'''á'''lín'''á'''</u>'' 'they have' (literally 'they are with'). This is followed by a plateau when positive, but not when negative: *''b<u>'''á'''lín'''á''' bálúg'''ú'''</u> mú'''ń'''gi'' 'they have many yams'<ref name=LBCxxii /> *''teb<u>'''á'''lín'''á'''</u> balug'''ú''' mú'''ń'''gi'' 'they don't have many yams'<ref name=LBCxxii />
====Verb + time==== A plateau is heard before words like ''jj'''ó''''' 'yesterday', ''lul'''í''''' 'the day before yesterday', and ''dd'''í''''' 'when?' in these sentences:<ref>''Luganda Basic Course'', p. 144.</ref> *''nay<u>'''ó'''zá jj'''ó'''</u> essa'''á'''ti en<u>ó</u>'' 'I washed this shirt yesterday' *''nas<u>s'''á'''líbwá lúl'''í'''</u> env'''í'''ir<u>í</u>'' 'I cut my hair the day before yesterday' *''wat<u>'''ú'''úká dd'''í'''</u> wan<u>ó</u>?'' 'when did you arrive here?'
But there is no plateau if the time adverb is toneless. Instead the adverb plateaus with the following word: *''nag'''ú'''la dd<u>(á) éssá'''á'''</u>ti en<u>ó</u>'' 'I bought this shirt a long time ago'
===Phrasal tone plateauing=== In contrast to lexical tones, words with a phrasal tone very easily make a plateau with the following word, as the following examples show (the plateaus are indicated by underlining): *''mu mamb<u>úká g'''á''' Úg'''áń'''</u>da'' 'in the north of Uganda'<ref name="LBC26"/> *''av<u>á mú Búg'''áń'''</u>da'' 'he comes from Buganda'<ref>''Luganda Basic Course'', p. 16.</ref> *''ab<u>ántú mú kíb'''ú'''</u>ga'' 'people in the city'<ref name=LBCxviii /> *''mu kyal<u>ó Másí'''ń'''</u>di'' 'in the village of Masindi'<ref name=LBCxviii /> *''eb<u>íjáńjááló byé bá'''á'''úzz'''ê'''</u>'' 'the beans that they bought'<ref name=LBCxviii /> *''ay<u>ágálá ókúlímá ámátóóké</u>'' 'he wants to cultivate bananas'<ref name=LBCxxii />
The phrasal high tone at the end of words like ''t'''ú'''gendá'' 'we are going' will also make a plateau in the same way, for example: *''t'''ú'''gend<u>á mú lúgúúdó</u>'' 'we are going into the street'<ref name="Luganda Basic Course, p.xxiii"/> *''b'''á'''fumb<u>é émm'''é'''</u>re'' 'they are cooking ''emmére'' (staple food)'<ref name=LBCxvii>''Luganda Basic Course'', p. xvii.</ref> *''amalw'''á'''al<u>író ámák'''ú'''</u>lu'' 'large hospitals'<ref name=LBCxvii />
Note that in these examples, it is not the lexical tone of words like ''t'''ú'''gendá'' which forms a plateau with the following high tone, but the phrasal tone at the end of the word. So there is first downdrift in ''t'''ú'''gendá'' and then a plateau.
In a sentence like the following, in which an HLH word like ''t'''ú'''gend<u>á</u>'' is used in a 'verb + location' sentence where the location has a lexical tone, according to Stevick, the plateau in such sentences will start with the lexical tone. However, the speaker on the recordings of the Luganda Basic Course in sentences of this kind makes a plateau starting only with the second tone, so that there is a downstep first then a plateau: *''t<u>'''ú'''géndá mú Úg'''áń'''</u>da'' 'we are going to Uganda' (according to Stevick)<ref>''Luganda Pretraining Program'', p. 193.</ref> *''t'''ú'''gend<u>á mú Úg'''áń'''</u>da'' 'we are going to Uganda' (as read on the recordings)<ref>''Luganda Basic Course'', p. 136; cf. p. 87, 88.</ref>
==Low tones then high==
The third common pattern in Luganda intonation is Low + High. This is only found if the first word is toneless. The following are some circumstances when no phrasal tones are added to a toneless word, and it has low tones throughout.
First, when it is the subject or topic of a sentence (unless it is a personal pronoun like ''ggw<u>é</u>'' 'you sg.'): *''Mbarara kib'''ú'''ga'' 'Mbarara is a city'.<ref>''Luganda Basic Course'', p. 30.</ref>
A toneless word also remains low-toned before a numeral or quantity word (except after a negative verb), e.g. *''ebitabo kk'''ú'''mi'' 'ten books'<ref name=LBC103 /> *''abantu b'''áń'''gi'' 'many people'<ref name=LBC103 /> *''amatooke amek'''á'''?'' 'how many bananas?'<ref>''Luganda Basic Course'', p. 156.</ref>
The word ''buli'' 'each' also remains low-toned when followed by another word: *''buli lun'''á'''ku'' 'each day'<ref name="Luganda Basic Course, p.xix"/> *''buli kit<u>ábó</u>'' 'every book'<ref name="Hyman 2017, p. 170"/>
An adverb or a subordinate clause can also form the topic of a sentence and be low-toned, e.g.<ref name=LBCxviii /><ref>See Hyman & Katamba (2010), p. 84, for further examples.</ref> *''oluvannyuma, b'''á'''lya emm'''é'''re'' 'afterwards, they eat ''emmére'' (staple food)' *''nga ayagala ebijanjaalo, abig'''ú'''la'' 'when he wants beans, he buys them'
==Falling tones== A high or a low tone may be found on any vowel, but a falling tone is found only on: *(a) a final vowel, e.g. ''egg'''î''''' 'egg'<ref>''Luganda Basic Course'', p. 331.</ref> *(b) a long vowel, e.g. ''okul'''ó'''ot<u>á</u>'' 'to dream'<ref name=DP127>Dutcher & Paster (2008), p. 127</ref> *(c) a vowel followed by a prenasalised consonant, e.g. ''Abag'''â'''nd<u>á</u>'' 'Baganda people' *(d) a vowel following a consonant + semivowel, e.g. ''okulw'''â'''l<u>á</u>'' 'to fall sick'<ref name="Luganda Basic Course, p.xiii"/> *(e) a short vowel followed by a geminate consonant, e.g. ''okub'''ô'''bb<u>á</u>'' 'to throb'.<ref name=DP127 />
When a falling tone occurs on a syllable closed by a geminate, such as in ''okuc'''ô'''pp<u>á</u>'' 'to become poor', the fall is very slight and hard to hear, though it can be measured instrumentally. The main way of telling that a word like this has a falling tone is that the tone on the following vowel is high.
===Morae=== One way of explaining these facts is to analyse Luganda words as consisting of [[mora (linguistics)|morae]] or moras, that is, speech segments each lasting a certain time. According to this analysis, a short vowel has one mora and a long vowel has two morae. A 'long' consonant such as ''gg'', ''mb'', or ''ly'' also has one mora. Thus the third syllable ''gâ'' of ''Abag'''â'''nd<u>á</u>'' can be said to be long by position, since it has two morae, one belonging to itself and the other 'borrowed from' or 'shared with' the prenasalised consonant which follows. A long syllable can have a falling tone, with the first mora high and the second mora low.
Certain accommodations have to be made to make the model fit. For example, an initial syllable starting with a vowel always counts as one mora, even in words like ''ens'''î''''' 'country' where the vowel is long and followed by a prenasalised consonant.<ref name="Luganda Basic Course, p.xiv">''Luganda Basic Course'', p. xiv.</ref>
No syllable can have more than two morae.<ref name="Luganda Basic Course, p.xi"/> For example, the second syllable of ''omw<u>éngé</u>'' 'beer' has only two, despite starting with ''mw'' and being followed by a prenasalised consonant.
===Final vowels=== Final vowels are usually pronounced short, but in some words (including all words with monosyllabic stems) the vowel becomes long before a suffix, for example ''ens'''î''': k'''í'''?'' 'which country?'.<ref>Hyman & Katamba (1993), p. 51.</ref><ref>Hyman & Katamba (1990).</ref> Final vowels which can become long are considered to have two morae. Certain other final vowels, such as the final ''-é'' of the subjunctive mood, are considered to have one mora.<ref>''Luganda Basic Course'', p. 183.</ref>
A final vowel therefore, if it is not toneless, can either have a high tone on the second mora (e.g. ''em'''ú''':'' 'one') or on the first mora (e.g. ''mwend'''â''''' 'nine'),<ref>''Luganda Basic Course'', p. 67.</ref> or on its single mora (''muyingir'''é''''' 'please come in').<ref name="Luganda Basic Course, p.182"/> All three of these, when at the end of a sentence, are pronounced with a falling tone. But in other contexts they have different pronunciations. For example, before the suffix ''k'''í''''' 'what?' a tone on the first mora of a bimoraic final vowel will fall (''ens'''î''' k'''í'''?'' 'what country?')<ref>''Luganda Basic Course'', p. 136.</ref> but a tone on the last mora will remain high (''tukol'''é''' k'''í'''?'' 'what should we do?').<ref name="Luganda Basic Course, p.182"/>
If a word ends in a falling tone, the tone becomes an ordinary high tone in some circumstances. One of these is when it is the subject of a sentence: *''K<u>'''á'''mpál'''á'''</u> kib'''ú'''ga'' 'Kampala is a city'<ref>''Luganda Basic Course'', p. 20.</ref> *''bonn'''á''' bawal'''â'''?'' 'are all of them girls?'<ref name=LBC103/>
Another is before a quantity word: *''balug'''ú''' m'''úń'''gi'' 'many yams'<ref name=LBCxxii />
Although there are now two high tones in adjacent syllables, nonetheless a downstep still occurs just as if the L part of the falling tone were still audible, so that in the above phrase ''mú'' is slightly lower in pitch than ''gú''.
==Nouns== Luganda nouns tend to fall tonally into certain regular patterns, of which the most common are (a) toneless (b) tone on the second mora from the end (c) tone on the third mora from the end. These three patterns together account for about 83% of nouns in Luganda. Some examples of the commonest patterns are as follows.
===Toneless nouns=== Judging from the numbers in the word list at the end of the ''Luganda Basic Course'', about one third of all nouns (32%) in Luganda are underlyingly toneless. However, when pronounced in isolation, they will have phrasal tones on all but the first mora (counting ''en-'' at the beginning of a word as one mora), as follows: *''ek<u>ítábó</u>'' 'book' *''ess<u>óméró</u>'' 'school' *''om<u>úntú</u>'' 'person' *''eng<u>áttó</u>'' 'shoe(s)' *''om<u>úlímú</u>'' 'work, job' *''om<u>úlénzí</u>'' 'boy' *''ak<u>ámwá</u>'' 'mouth' *''ol<u>úpápúlá</u>'' 'paper' *''ent<u>é</u>'' 'cow(s)' *''env<u>á</u>'' 'relish' *''am<u>átá</u>'' 'milk'
===Penultimate tone=== Also very common, about 26% of the words, are nouns with a penultimate tone, that is on the second mora from the end of the word. If the penultimate syllable is long, as in ''eny'''áń'''ja'' 'lake', both moras are high-toned. What all these nouns have in common is that the last vowel cannot take a phrasal tone. Examples are: *''ent'''é'''be'' 'chair' *''ekib'''ú'''ga'' 'city' *''emb'''ú'''zi'' 'goat' *''ekik'''ó'''po'' 'cup' *''omuk'''ó'''no'' 'hand, arm' *''eny'''áń'''ja'' 'lake' *''ens'''íḿ'''bi'' 'money' *''ká'''á'''wa'' 'coffee'
===Antepenultimate tone=== Nouns which have a high tone on the third mora from the end of the word (e.g. ''akag'''á'''ali'' 'bicycle') are also very common, and the various types listed below account for at least 25% of the vocabulary.
When used before a pause, or before a pronominal word like ''ban<u>ó</u>'' 'these' or ''bonn'''â''''' 'all' (see above) these words acquire a phrasal tone on the final syllable: *''akag'''á'''al<u>í</u> ak<u>ó</u>'' 'that bicycle'<ref>''Luganda Basic Course'', p.169.</ref>
However, in other contexts no phrasal tone is added, and there is no plateau with the following word: *''omw'''á'''aka og<u>'''ú'''yís'''ê'''</u>'' 'last year'<ref>''Luganda Basic Course'', p. 145.</ref> *''sá'''á'''nywedde m'''á'''zzi ku kanky'''â''''' 'I didn't drink water for breakfast'.<ref name=LBC141>''Luganda Basic Course'', p.141.</ref>
Contrast the following example, where the phrasal tone of ''mat<u>á</u>'' 'milk' makes a plateau with the following word.<ref name=LBC141 /> *''sá'''á'''nywedde mat<u>á kú kánky</u>'''â''''' 'I didn't drink milk for breakfast'
Some nouns of this type are: *''am'''á'''as<u>ó</u>'' 'eyes' *''omw'''â'''n<u>á</u>'' 'child' *''omw'''â'''k<u>á</u>'' 'year' *''omw'''ê'''z<u>í</u>'' 'month' *''eny'''á'''any<u>á</u>'' 'tomatoes' *''am'''â'''zzi'' 'water' *''c'''á'''ayi'' 'tea' *''ssuk'''á'''ari'' 'sugar' *''akag'''á'''ali'' 'bicycle' *''emm'''é'''eri'' 'ship' *''ekit'''û'''ndu'' 'part' *''er'''î'''nnya'' 'name' *''Abag'''â'''nda'' 'Baganda people'
To these can be added a few nouns with the tone on the antepenultimate syllable, which are all marked by Stevick as HLL: *''ebugw'''áń'''juba'' 'west' *''ebuv'''áń'''juba'' 'east' *''ek'''í'''bala'' 'fruit' *''ekk'''ó'''lero'' 'workshop' *''omus'''ó'''mesa'' 'teacher'
Hyman draws attention to the word ''ek'''í'''bala'' ('fruit'), which is unusual in having an accent on the class-prefix. He suggests that this is either because it may be a borrowing from another Ugandan language, [[Soga language|Soga]], or because it is a derivative of the verb ''-b'''á'''la'' ('bear fruit').<ref name="Hyman 2017, p. 170"/>
A few nouns (mostly foreign) have a double tone followed by LL: *''<u>'''Á'''m'''é'''</u>reka'' 'America' *''Omus<u>'''í'''r'''á'''</u>amu'' 'Muslim' *''Oluf<u>'''á'''l'''á'''</u>nsa'' 'French (language)' *''enn<u>'''í'''m'''á'''</u>awa'' 'lemon' (Portuguese ''limão'') *''amat<u>'''á'''f'''á'''</u>ali'' 'brick'<ref>''Luganda Basic Course'', p. 292.</ref>
===Falling tone on the final=== About 9% of the nouns have a falling tone on the final. The shorter of these nouns (up to three moras) have a single tone: *''ens'''î''''' 'country' *''egg'''î''''' 'egg' *''embw'''â''''' 'dog' *''balug'''û''''' 'yam(s)' *''omut'''î''''' 'tree'
The longer nouns have a second tone earlier in the word, which links into a plateau: *''ekib<u>'''í'''ín'''â'''</u>'' 'class' *''ekk<u>'''ó'''mér'''â'''</u>'' 'prison' *''olub<u>'''á'''áw'''ô'''</u>'' 'board' *''edd<u>'''ú'''úk'''â'''</u>'' 'shop' *''eky<u>'''é'''ńky'''â'''</u>'' 'breakfast' *''obuk<u>'''í'''ík'''â'''</u>'' 'direction'
A few less common nouns have a tone on the penultimate and the final:<ref>''Luganda Basic Course'', p. xvi.</ref><ref name=HK62>Hyman & Katamba (1993), p. 62.</ref> *''mug<u>'''ó'''b'''â'''</u>'' 'driver' *''mus<u>'''í'''k'''â'''</u>'' 'heir'
===Other patterns=== A very few words (about 2%) have the tone far enough from the end of the word to allow for two phrasal tones following the HL of the lexical tone: *''amas'''é'''reng<u>étá</u>'' 'the south' *''edd'''wâ'''l<u>író</u>'' 'hospital'
Other patterns are possible, for example ''Olw'''ó'''kusat<u>ú</u>'' 'Wednesday' (ending in HLLL), but these patterns account for only a small percentage of the nouns.
===Variable tone nouns=== There are certain words in Luganda which have a high tone on the third mora, and in which the tone shifts to the following mora when the word is used without its initial vowel:<ref>Hyman & Katamba (1993), p. 58.</ref> *''Abag'''â'''nda'' 'Baganda people' - ''Bag'''áń'''da'' 'they are Baganda' *''omus'''ó'''mesa'' 'teacher' - ''musom'''é'''sa'' 'he is a teacher' *''omuw'''á'''la'' 'girl' - ''muwal'''â''''' 'she is a girl' *''omut'''á'''miivu'' 'drunkard' - ''mutam'''í'''ivu'' 'he is a drunkard'
Hyman and Katamba note that the same alternations take place in certain verb tenses: *''agul'''â''''' 'he who buys' - ''abig'''ú'''la'' 'he who buys them' *''alag'''í'''ra'' 'he who commands' - ''atul'''á'''gira'' 'he who commands us' *''ayá'''á'''mba'' 'he who helps' - ''atuy'''á'''amba'' 'he who helps us'
A similar alternation occurs in numbers 1-5, and the words for 'yours' and 'his', with two differences, one that the tone comes on the second mora, and secondly that with a monosyllabic stem, the tone on the final is not deleted: *''bis'''á'''tu'' - ''eb'''í'''satu'' 'three (e.g. books)' *''bin'''â''''' - ''eb'''í'''n'''â''''' 'four' *''biby'''ô''''' - ''eb'''í'''by'''ô''''' 'your ones (e.g. books)'
A few foreign nouns (mostly from Swahili) are also irregular, in that they have an extra tone in the plural or in the diminutive where the prefix has an extra syllable:<ref name=HK62 /> *''bbak'''ú'''li'' 'bowl' - plural ''mab'''á'''k'''ú'''li'' 'bowls' *''ggun'''í'''ya'' 'sack' - plural ''mag'''ú'''n'''í'''ya'' 'sacks' *''kkal'''á'''amu'' 'pen, pencil' - plural ''mak'''á'''l'''á'''amu'' *''mbal'''á'''asi'' 'horse' - diminutive ''kab'''á'''l'''á'''asi'' 'little horse'
==Possessive pronouns ('my', 'our' etc.)== Possessive pronouns in Luganda are of two types, those with two syllables, namely ''-ange'' 'my', ''-affe'' 'our', ''-ammwe'' 'your (pl.)', ''-aabwe'' (pronounced [''-aawwe'']) 'their' and those with one syllable, namely ''-'''ô''''' 'your' and ''-'''ê''''' 'his, her, its'.
The two-syllable possessives used on their own have an HLL tone: ''ekky'''â'''nge'' 'my one (e.g. place, book, etc.)',<ref name="Luganda Basic Course, p.172">''Luganda Basic Course'', p. 172.</ref> ''ew'''â'''ffe'' 'our home'.<ref>''Luganda Basic Course'', p. 80.</ref> However, when they are used with a noun, they become enclitic, and if the noun is HLL this tone goes on the final vowel of the noun, making a plateau with the earlier tone: *''er<u>'''í'''ńny'''á'''</u> lyange'' (before a pause, ''lyang<u>é</u>'') 'my name'<ref name="Luganda Basic Course, p.2-3">''Luganda Basic Course'', p. 2-3.</ref> *''okus<u>'''ó'''més'''á'''</u> wange'' 'my teacher'<ref name=LBC163>''Luganda Basic Course'', p. 163.</ref> *''akag<u>'''á'''ál'''í'''</u> kange'' 'my bicycle'<ref name=LBC163 /> *''c<u>'''á'''áy'''í'''</u> waffe'' 'our tea'<ref name=LBC157>''Luganda Basic Course'', p. 157.</ref> *''am<u>'''á'''zz'''í'''</u> waffe'' 'our water'<ref name=LBC157 />
If added to a noun with a falling tone on the final, the final tone changes from falling to high: *''ens'''í''': yange'' 'my country'<ref>''Luganda Basic Course'', p. 56</ref> *''edd<u>'''ú'''úk'''á'''</u> yange'' 'my shop' *''amag'''í''' gaffe'' 'our eggs'<ref name=LBC157 />
Otherwise if the noun has penultimate tone, the tone on the final vowel is deleted by Meeussen's rule (HH > HL): *''ekib'''ú'''ga kyange'' 'my city'
When used with a toneless noun, however, the high tone migrates from the final syllable to the third mora of the noun. The tones which follow it are all L: *''ekit'''á'''bo kyange'' 'my book'<ref name=LBC184>''Luganda Basic Course'', p. 184.</ref> *''kitab'''ó''' kyange'' '(it is) my book'<ref name="Luganda Basic Course, p.xiv"/> *''ebit'''á'''bo byaabwe'' 'their books'<ref name="Luganda Basic Course, p.172"/> *''kitó'''ó'''ke kyange'' 'my plantain tree'<ref name=HK49>Hyman & Katamba (1993), p. 49.</ref> *''kisum'''ú'''luzo kyange'' 'my key'<ref name=HK49 /> *''olup'''á'''pula lwange'' 'my paper'<ref name=LBC184 />
(The above rules are those given in the literature. In practice, however, the reader on the ''Luganda Basic Course'' recordings sometimes adds a tone on the final syllable of the noun even where it is theoretically not permitted: ''ens<u>'''í'''mb'''í'''</u> zaabwe'' 'their money',<ref>''Luganda Basic Course'', p. 186.</ref> ''emig<u>'''á'''át'''í'''</u> gyaffe'' 'our loaves', where the text writes ''emigáàtì'',<ref>''Luganda Basic Course'', p. 185, cf. p. 168.</ref> ''ekit'''á'''b'''ó''' kyange'' 'my book'.<ref name="Luganda Basic Course, p.168"/>)
When the noun is a foreign borrowing, such as ''kitaamb'''á'''ala'' 'table-cloth' or ''mabal'''ú'''wa'' 'letters', it is reported that the high tone plateau starts not on the accented mora, but the second mora of the word:<ref>Kalema (1977), p. 133.</ref> *''ki<u>táámb'''á'''ál'''á'''</u> kyaffe'' 'our table cloth' *''ma<u>bál'''ú'''</u>wa gaange'' 'my letters'
With a monosyllabic possessive namely ''-'''ô''''' 'your' or ''-'''ê''''' 'his', the tones are different. The first tone remains in the same place as before, then there is a plateau from the first tone to the end: *''ekit<u>'''á'''bó ky'''ô'''</u>'' 'your book'<ref name="Luganda Basic Course, p.56">''Luganda Basic Course'', p. 56.</ref> *''er<u>'''í'''ńnyá ly'''ô'''</u>'' 'your name'<ref name="Luganda Basic Course, p.2-3"/> *''ekib<u>'''ú'''gá ky'''ô'''</u>'' 'your city'<ref name="Luganda Basic Course, p.56"/> *''akag<u>'''á'''álí k'''é'''</u>'' 'his bicycle'<ref name="Luganda Basic Course, p.172"/>
But when the noun has a tone on the final syllable, it becomes a high tone, and the tone of -''yó'' is suppressed by Meeussen's rule (HH > HL): *''ens'''í''': yo'' 'your country' *''mu kib<u>'''í'''ín'''á''':</u> kyo'' 'in your class'
==Verbs==
===High and low-toned verbs=== Like many Bantu languages, Luganda has high-toned and low-toned verbs. In the infinitive, low-toned verbs have the usual phrasal tones on all but the first mora: *''ok<u>úsá</u>'' 'to grind' *''okw<u>érá</u>'' 'to sweep' *''ok<u>úggálá</u>'' 'to shut' *''ok<u>újjá</u>'' 'to come' *''ok<u>úlíndá</u>'' 'to wait' *''ok<u>úsómá</u>'' 'to study, read' *''ok<u>úsómésá</u>'' to teach' *''ok<u>úgúlá</u>'' 'to buy'
High-toned verbs (which are about 60% of verbs) have a high tone on the mora immediately following the infinitive prefix ''oku-''. Phrasal tones are added only in the case of longer verbs: *''okuly'''â''''' 'to eat' *''okunyw'''â''''' 'to drink' *''okut'''ú'''ma'' 'to send' *''okul'''á'''ba'' 'to see' *''okuk'''ó'''la'' 'to work, to do' *''okuf'''ú'''na'' 'to get, obtain' *''okuy'''î'''mb<u>á</u>'' 'to sing' *''okut'''â'''nd<u>íká</u>'' 'to begin' *''okuy'''î'''ng<u>írá</u>'' 'to enter'
===Meeussen's rule (HH > HL)=== Verbs in Luganda are particularly affected by a rule known as [[Meeussen's rule]], which is common in many African languages, whereby a sequence of tones HH becomes HL. Similarly HHH becomes HLL and HHHH becomes HLLL. (This rule does not affect nouns in Luganda.)
Thus *''b'''á'''-l'''í'''-l'''á'''ba'' 'they will see' theoretically has three high tones, one for the prefix ''b'''á'''-'' 'they', one for the future tense-marker ''-l'''í'''-'', and one for the verb-stem itself ''l'''á'''ba'' 'see'. However, after the operation of Meeussen's rule, and the addition of a phrasal tone, it changes as follows:<ref name="Hyman & Katamba 1993, pp.36, 45">Hyman & Katamba (1993), pp. 36, 45.</ref> * *''b'''á'''-l'''í'''-l'''á'''ba'' > ''b'''á'''lilab<u>á</u>'' 'they will see'
The important point here is that a phrasal tone cannot be added (except on the very last syllable before a pause) to any syllable that formerly had a high tone. Thus in the above word ''b'''á'''lilab<u>á</u>'' the remaining lexical tone on ''b'''á''''' is followed not by one low-toned syllable, but by two.
Hyman and Katamba give the following examples to illustrate how a lowered H cannot acquire a phrasal tone or form a plateau:<ref name="Hyman & Katamba 1993, p.45"/> *''b'''á'''lilab<u>á ébík'''ó'''</u>po'' 'they will see cups' (with a plateau), where ''b'''á'''lilaba'' is derived from *''b'''á'''l'''í'''l'''á'''ba'' *''ab'''á'''lilaba ebik'''ó'''po'' 'they who will see cups' (with downdrift), where ''ab'''á'''lilaba'' is derived from *''ab'''á'''l'''í'''l'''á'''b'''á'''''
To make sense of the tones of Luganda verbs therefore, it is necessary to consider not only what tones the verb actually has, but also the underlying tones which it formerly had before the operation of Meeussen's rule.
===Tones in tenses=== Various elements add a tone to verbs:<ref>''Luganda Basic Course'', p. xiv ff.</ref> *The tone of the subject prefix. This usually has a tone if it is 'diphonic' (consisting of two phonemes) such as ''b'''á'''-'' 'they', ''t'''ú'''-'' 'we', ''k'''í'''''- 'it' etc, but usually toneless if it is monophonic (consisting of one phoneme), e.g. ''a''- 'he/she', ''n-'' 'I', ''o''- 'you (sg.)' etc. (For an exception see below on relative clause verbs.) *The tone of the tense-marker. The tense-markers -'''''á'''''- (Near Past), -''n'''á'''a''- (Near Future), -''l'''í'''''- (General Future), -''ky'''á'''''- ('still') all add a tone, while -''a''- (Far Past) adds a tone in the syllable which follows. (The tense-markers -''nna''- 'not yet' and -''aaka''- 'just' do not add a tone; there is also no tone in the ending ''-nga'' used to make the habitual aspect.) *The tone of the verb-stem, if it is high-toned. In the Infinitive and General Future this tone is on the first mora only, but in the Present tense it affects the first two moras. *The tone of the negative marker. The 1st person negative marker ''s'''í'''-'' has its own tone. The negative marker with other persons is ''te-'', which adds a tone on the following syllable. In relative-clause verbs the negative marker is -''t'''á'''''-. *In addition, many tenses add a grammatical tone on the final syllable. In longer verbs, in some cases this tone may move to the penultimate syllable.
Having added these tones, the following rules apply:
*Any sequence HLH (HLLH, HLLLH) becomes a plateau by the plateauing rule, for example ''teb'''á'''gul'''á''''' becomes ''teb<u>'''á'''gúl'''â'''</u>'' 'they do not buy'. *Any sequence HH (HHH, HHHH) becomes HL (HLL, HLLL) by Meeussen's rule, unless there is a plateau; for example ''b'''á'''l'''á'''b'''á''''' becomes ''b'''á'''laba'' 'they see'. *Phrasal tones are added to the end of the verb, except that: :(a) A phrasal tone is not added to any syllable of which the tone has been deleted by Meeussen's rule, except at the end of a sentence or before pronominal words such as ''bonn'''â''''' 'all'. :(b) A phrasal tone also does not directly follow the General Future infix -''l'''í'''''- in low-toned verbs, even if the tone of -''l'''í'''''- is deleted.
===Relative clause verbs=== Relative clause verbs have a different intonation from ordinary verbs in Luganda. They are more commonly used than in English, since as Crabtree pointed out (1902) they are used for emphasis.<ref>Crabtree (1902), p. 145.</ref> For example, instead of 'who bought things?' a Luganda-speaker would say 'which are the ones who bought things?' *''bak'''í''' ab<u>'''á'''gúz'''é'''</u> ebintu?''<ref>''Luganda Basic Course'', p. 240.</ref>
Similarly, instead of 'he went to Buganda to teach', a Luganda-speaker might say 'what he went to Buganda for is to teach':<ref>''Luganda Basic Course'', p. 188.</ref> *''y<u>'''á'''génd'''á''' mú Búgá'''ń'''</u>da kus<u>ómésá</u>'' 'what he went to Buganda for is to teach'
An initial vowel is usually added before diphonic subject-prefixes such as ''b'''á'''-'' (e.g. ''ab<u>'''á'''gúl'''â'''</u>'' 'they who buy'), but not before monophonic prefixes such as ''a-''. However, this initial vowel disappears in certain contexts, such as the second example above.
In object clauses, such as the following, a toneless prefix acquires a tone:<ref>''Luganda Basic Course'', p. xxi.</ref> *''emm'''é'''re gye '''<u>á'''fú'''ḿ'''</u>ba'' 'the staple food which she is cooking'
But when an object copula is used as in the following sentence, both kinds of prefix lose their tone: *''emm'''é'''re gye bafú'''ḿ'''ba'' 'the staple food is what they are cooking'.
The word ''gwe'', ''ge'', ''bye'' etc. itself usually has no tone. However, the rules for such clauses can be complex.<ref>See Hyman & Katamba (2010), pp. 87ff.</ref>
===Examples of tenses===
In the tables which follow, examples are given of six commonly used tenses, together with the subjunctive mood, with some comments on each. In the tables two verbs are used, ''-gula'' 'buy' and -''l'''á'''ba'' 'see', as examples of low and high-toned verbs respectively.<ref>''Luganda Basic Course'', pp. xxv-xxxv.</ref>
====Present tense====
{| class="wikitable" style="text-align: center; width: 600px; height: 100px;" |+ ! ! basic ! relative ! negative ! neg. rel. |- ! 'he buys' |''ag<u>úlá</u>''||''agul'''â'''''||''t<u>'''á'''gúl'''â'''</u>''||''at<u>'''á'''gúl'''â'''</u>'' |- ! 'he sees' |''al'''á'''ba''||''al'''á'''ba''||''t'''á'''laba''||''at'''á'''laba'' |- ! 'they buy' |''b'''á'''gul<u>á</u>''||''ab<u>'''á'''gúl'''â'''</u>'' ||''teb<u>'''á'''gúl'''â'''</u>''||''ab<u>'''á'''tágúl'''â'''</u>'' |- ! 'they see' |''b'''á'''laba''||''ab'''á'''laba'' ||''teb'''á'''laba''||''ab'''á'''talaba'' |- |}
The underlying tones of the 3rd person plural of the high-toned verb change by Meeussen's rule as follows: * *''b'''á'''-l'''á'''b'''á''''' > ''b'''á'''laba'' 'they see' (HHH > HLL)
That is, the first ''two'' moras of the verb-stem in this tense are underlyingly high. (Compare ''b'''á'''sesem<u>á</u>'' 'they vomit'; ''b'''á'''tand<u>íká</u>'' 'they begin'.)
When an object-infix such as ''-gu-'' 'it (e.g. bread)' is added, the tones change as follows: * *''b'''á'''-gu-l'''á'''b'''á''''' > ''b<u>'''á'''gúl'''á'''</u>ba'' 'they see it'
The negative and relative versions of this tense all have a grammatical tone on the final vowel, which in fact has two moras and is underlyingly *''-a'''á'''''. In a two-mora high-toned verb, this final tone disappears by Meeussen's rule, but it reappears and makes a plateau when the verb-stem has three moras or more: *''teb'''á'''laba'' 'they do not see' (HHHH > HLL) *''teb<u>'''á'''léét'''â'''</u>'' 'they do not bring' (HHLH > HHH)
When the irregular verb ''-li'' 'is (in a certain location)' is used in a relative clause, a high tone is placed on the final vowel when the prefix is toneless. But when the prefix has a tone, the tone on the final is deleted by Meeussen's rule. The tone therefore varies according to whether the prefix is monophonic or diphonic: *''al<u>í</u>'' 'he is' - ''al'''í''''' 'who is' *''b'''á'''li'' 'they are' - ''ab'''á'''li'' 'who are'
The two words ''al<u>í</u>'' and ''al'''í''''', although both end in high tones, are pronounced differently in contexts such as the following, where the tone of ''al'''í''''' is higher and does not make a plateau:<ref name="Luganda Basic Course, p.219"/> *''al<u>í mú Búg'''áń'''</u>da'' 'he is in Buganda' *''al'''í''' mu Bug'''áń'''da'' 'who is in Buganda'
====Perfect tense====
{| class="wikitable" style="text-align: center; width: 600px; height: 100px;" |+ ! ! basic ! relative ! negative ! neg. rel. |- ! 'he has bought' |''aguz'''ê'''''||''aguz'''ê'''''||''t<u>'''á'''gúz'''ê'''</u>''||''at<u>'''á'''gúz'''ê'''</u>'' |- ! 'he has seen' |''al'''á'''bye''||''al<u>'''á'''by'''ê'''</u>''||''t<u>'''á'''láby'''ê'''</u>''||''at<u>'''á'''láby'''ê'''</u>'' |- ! 'they have bought' |''b<u>'''á'''gúz'''ê'''</u>''||''ab<u>'''á'''gúz'''ê'''</u>''||''teb<u>'''á'''gúz'''ê'''</u>''||''ab<u>'''á'''tágúz'''ê'''</u>'' |- ! 'they have seen' |''b'''á'''labye''||''ab<u>'''á'''láby'''ê'''</u>''||''teb<u>'''á'''láby'''ê'''</u>''||''ab<u>'''á'''táláby'''ê'''</u>'' |- |}
The Perfect tense uses a different stem from the Present (e.g. ''-guz'''ê''''' instead of ''-gula'' 'buy'), and there is an underlying high tone on the ending. In longer (3-mora) low-toned verbs, such as ''-genda'' 'go' or ''-kweka'' 'hide (something)', the final tone moves to the penultimate syllable in the basic form: *''agé'''ń'''ze'' 'she has gone' (not *''agenz'''ê''''' as one might expect)
All the forms of this tense have a tone on the final vowel, but the basic form is different from the negative and relative. In high-toned verbs, Meeussen's rule applies in the basic form (e.g. ''b'''á'''labye'' 'they have seen'), but in the negative and relative forms there is a plateau instead (''teb<u>'''á'''láby'''ê'''</u>'' they have not seen'). Another example, using the 1st person negative marker ''s'''í'''-'', which keeps its own tone, is the following: *''nt'''é'''gedde'' 'I have understood' vs. ''s<u>'''í'''tégédd'''ê'''</u>'' 'I have not understood'<ref>''Luganda Basic Course'', p. 15.</ref>
====Near Past tense====
{| class="wikitable" style="text-align: center; width: 600px; height: 100px;" |+ ! ! basic ! relative ! negative ! neg. rel. |- ! 'he bought (today)' |''y<u>'''á'''gúz'''ê'''</u>''||''ey<u>'''á'''gúz'''ê'''</u>''||''tey'''á'''guze''||''atá'''á'''guze'' |- ! 'he saw' |''y<u>'''á'''láby'''ê'''</u>''||''ey<u>'''á'''láby'''ê'''</u>''||''tey'''á'''labye''||''atá'''á'''labye'' |- ! 'they bought' |''b<u>'''áá'''gúz'''ê'''</u>''||''ab<u>'''áá'''gúz'''ê'''</u>''||''tebá'''á'''guze''||''ab<u>'''á'''tá'''á'''</u>guze'' |- ! 'they saw' |''b<u>'''áá'''láby'''ê'''</u>''||''ab<u>'''áá'''láby'''ê'''</u>''||''tebá'''á'''labye''||''ab<u>'''á'''tá'''á'''</u>labye'' |- |}
The Near Past tense uses the same verb-stem as the Perfect tense but with the tense marker -'''''á'''''-. The subject prefixes change to ''y'''á'''-'' 'he' and ''b'''áá'''-'' 'they'. The final vowel once again is -'''ê'''''.
In low-toned verbs the subject prefix makes a plateau with the grammatical tone on the final vowel: *''y<u>'''á'''-gúz'''ê'''</u>'' 'he bought (today)' (from ''ok<u>úgúlá</u>'' 'to buy')
In longer low-toned verbs in this tense the final tone moves to the second mora of the penultimate syllable:<ref>''Luganda Basic Course'', p.xxvii.</ref> *''y<u>'''á'''kẃ'''é'''</u>se'' 'he hid (today)' (from ''ok<u>úkwéká</u>'' 'to hide something')
In high-toned verbs in this tense there is always a plateau even in the basic form of the verb (in this it differs from the Perfect tense above). Contrast: *''b'''á'''labye'' 'he has seen' (from ''okul'''á'''ba'' 'to see') *''b<u>'''áá'''-láby'''ê'''</u>'' 'he saw (today)'
====Far Past tense====
{| class="wikitable" style="text-align: center; width: 600px; height: 100px;" |+ ! ! basic ! relative ! negative ! neg. rel. |- ! 'he bought' |''yag'''ú'''la''||''eyag'''ú'''la''||''teyag'''ú'''la''||''atá'''á'''gula'' |- ! 'he saw' |''yal'''á'''ba''||''eyal'''á'''ba''||''teyal'''á'''ba''||''atá'''á'''laba'' |- ! 'they bought' |''bá'''á'''gula''||''abá'''á'''gula''||''tebá'''á'''gula''||''ab<u>'''á'''tá'''á'''</u>gula'' |- ! 'they saw' |''bá'''á'''laba''||''abá'''á'''laba''||''tebá'''á'''laba''||''ab<u>'''á'''tá'''á'''</u>laba'' |- |}
The tense-infix of this tense is ''a'', which puts a tone on the syllable which follows it.
Although the forms in the table above do not appear to have a high tone on the final, in fact there is an underlying high tone, which reappears and makes a plateau in forms like the following: *''ya-g<u>'''ú'''-kwékâ</u> 'he hid it'
Another indication that there is an underlying high tone on the final vowel is the fact that forms like ''bá'''á'''gula'' 'they bought' do not add a phrasal tone on the final syllable (except before a pause or before a pronominal word like ''bonn'''â''''' 'all').
====Near Future tense====
{| class="wikitable" style="text-align: center; width: 600px; height: 100px;" |+ ! ! basic ! relative ! negative ! neg. rel. |- ! 'he will buy (today)' |''an'''á'''ag<u>úlá</u>''||''an<u>'''á'''agúl'''â'''</u>''||''t<u>'''á'''ágúl'''ê'''</u>''||''at<u>'''á'''ágúl'''ê'''</u>'' |- ! 'he will see' |''an<u>'''á'''ál'''á'''</u>ba''||''an<u>'''á'''ál'''á'''</u>ba''||''t<u>'''á'''ál'''á'''</u>be''||''at<u>'''á'''ál'''á'''</u>be'' |- ! 'they will buy' |''b'''á'''naag<u>úlá</u>''||''ab<u>'''á'''náágúl'''â'''</u>''||''teb<u>'''á'''ágúl'''ê'''</u>''||''ab<u>'''á'''táágúl'''ê'''</u>'' |- ! 'they will see' |''b<u>'''á'''náál'''á'''</u>ba''||''ab<u>'''á'''náál'''á'''ba''||''teb<u>'''á'''ál'''á'''</u>be''||''ab<u>'''á'''táágúl'''á'''</u>be'' |- |}
The Near Future tense has a tense-marker -''n'''á'''-a''-. In the relative and negative forms, there is an (underlying) grammatical tone on the final vowel. In the negative of this tense, the final vowel changes to ''-e''.
In the second person singular -''n'''á'''-a''- becomes ''n'''ó'''-o-'':<ref>''Luganda Basic Course'', p. 259.</ref> * *''o-n'''á'''-a-ly'''â''''' > ''on<u>'''ó'''oly'''â'''</u>'' 'you (sg.) will eat'
====General Future tense====
{| class="wikitable" style="text-align: center; width: 600px; height: 100px;" |+ ! ! basic ! relative ! negative ! neg. rel. |- ! 'he will buy' |''al'''í'''gul<u>á</u>''||''al<u>'''í'''gúl'''â'''</u>''||''t'''á'''ligul<u>á</u>''||''at'''á'''ligul<u>á</u>'' |- ! 'he will see' |''al'''í'''lab<u>á</u>'' (?)||''al'''í'''laba''||''t'''á'''lilaba''||''at'''á'''lilaba'' |- ! 'they will buy' |''b'''á'''ligul<u>á</u>''||''ab<u>'''á'''lígúl'''â'''</u>''||''teb'''á'''ligul<u>á</u>''||''ab'''á'''taligul<u>á</u>'' |- ! 'they will see' |''b'''á'''lilab<u>á</u>''||''ab'''á'''lilaba''||''teb'''á'''lilab<u>á</u>''||''ab'''á'''talilab<u>á</u>'' |- |}
This tense has a tone on the tense-marker ''-l'''í'''-''. The tone of this disappears by Meeussen's rule after a high-toned subject prefix. A peculiarity of this tense is that with a low-toned verb, the syllable after ''-l'''í'''-'' cannot bear a phrasal tone, even when the tone of ''-l'''í'''-'' itself is deleted by Meeussen's rule.
The forms given above differ from those given by Stevick,<ref>''Luganda Basic Course'', p. xxxiv.</ref> who states that in this tense as in the Present the first two moras of a high-toned verb stem have underlying tone. However, the examples given by Hyman and Katamba (e.g. ''b'''á'''liwul<u>írá</u>'' 'they will hear')<ref name="Hyman & Katamba 1993, pp.36, 45"/> imply that only the first mora of a high-toned verb has an underlying tone in this tense. Contrast the Present tense example below, in which both syllables of ''-laba'' are low, with the Future tense, where only the second syllable has a phrasal tone: *''b'''á'''laba om<u>úgáátí</u>'' 'they see bread'<ref>''Luganda Basic Course'', p. xxxi.</ref> *''b'''á'''lilab<u>á ébík</u>'''ó'''po'' 'they will see cups'<ref>Hyman & Katamba 1993, p. 45</ref>
====Subjunctive mood====
*''agul'''ê''''' 'he should buy' *''alab'''ê''''' 'he should see' *''bagul'''ê''''' 'they should buy' *''balab'''ê''''' 'they should see'
The subjunctive mood has just a single tone on the final vowel, which causes all earlier tones in the verb to be deleted. Before a pause, this tone becomes a falling tone, but before ''kí?'' 'what?', it remains high:<ref name="Luganda Basic Course, p.182"/> *''muyingir'''ê''''' 'please come in, you should come in' *''tukol'''é''' k'''í'''?'' 'what should we do?'
Contrast the following, where the final vowel has a falling tone and two moras:<ref name="Luganda Basic Course, p.xiv"/> *''ens'''î''' k'''í'''?'' 'what country?' er The subjunctive has no relative clause or negative form, but a negative may be made by using the subjunctive of the verb ''ok<u>úlémá</u>'' 'to fail' plus the infinitive.<ref>''Luganda Basic Course'', p. 254.</ref> *''balem'''é''' okuy'''î'''ng<u>írá</u>'' 'they should not come in'<ref>''Luganda Basic Course'', p. 252.</ref>
==Object infixes== An object infix such as ''-m'''ú'''-'' 'him/her' or ''-b'''á'''-'' 'them' can be added to a verb before the verb-root. In the infinitive, object infixes have a tone:<ref>Hyman (2017), p. 168.</ref> *''oku-m'''ú'''-siba'' 'to tie him/her' *''oku-b'''á'''-siba'' 'to tie them'
However, in the present tense, they are toneless: *''a-mu-siba'' 'he ties him/her'
But the reflexive infix is always high-toned, even in the present tense: *''okw-'''éé'''-siba'' 'to tie oneself' *''y-'''éé'''-siba'' 'he ties himself/she ties herself'
==See also== [[Chichewa tones]]
==References== {{reflist|2}}
==Bibliography== * Crabtree, William Arthur (1902). ''Elements of Luganda Grammar: Together With Exercises and Vocabulary''. Reprint. London: Forgotten Books, 2013. * Dutcher, Katharine & Mary Paster (2008), [http://www.lingref.com/cpp/wccfl/27/paper1824.pdf "Contour Tone Distribution in Luganda"] ''Proceedings of the 27th West Coast Conference on Formal Linguistics'', ed. Natasha Abner and Jason Bishop, 123-131. Somerville, MA: Cascadilla Proceedings Project. * Hyman, Larry M. (2009). [http://linguistics.berkeley.edu/~hyman/papers/2009-hyman-pitchaccent.pdf "How (not) to do phonological typology: the case of pitch-accent"]. ''Language Sciences'' 31, 213–238. *Hyman, Larry M. & Francis X. Katamba (1990). "Final vowel shortening in Luganda". ''Studies in African Linguistics'' 21, 1-59. * Hyman, Larry M. & Francis X. Katamba (1993). [https://www.jstor.org/stable/416415 "A new approach to tone in Luganda"], in ''Language''. 69. 1. pp. 33–67. * Hyman, Larry M. & Francis X. Katamba (2010). [http://www.zas.gwz-berlin.de/fileadmin/material/ZASPiL_Volltexte/zp53/9_Hyman_Katamba.pdf "Tone, syntax, and prosodic domains in Luganda"]. ZAS Papers in Linguistics 53, pp. 69–98. * Hyman, L.M. (2017). [http://www.linguistics.berkeley.edu/phonlab/documents/2017/Hyman_Bantu_Tone_Overview.pdf "Bantu Tone Overview"]. UC Berkeley Phonetics and Phonology Lab Annual Report (2017) * Kalema, John (1977). [http://journals.linguisticsociety.org/elanguage/sal/article/download/1024/1024-2189-1-PB.pdf "Accent modification rules in Luganda"]. ''Studies in African Linguistics'', vol. 8, no. 2. * Kamoga, F.K. & [[Earl Stevick|Stevick]] (1968). [http://www.fsi-language-courses.net/languages/Luganda/Basic/FSI%20-%20Luganda%20Basic%20Course%20-%20Instructor%20and%20Student%20Text.pdf ''Luganda Basic Course'']. Foreign Service Institute, Washington. Sound files of this course are available free on the Internet. * Kamoga, F.K. & Stevick, E.W. (1968). ''Luganda Pretraining Program''. Foreign Service Institute, Washington.

revision.comment: Moving {{Translated page}} to [[Talk:Miren Agur Meabe]]. If this bot is making errors, please report it at [[User:AnomieBOT/shutoff/TalkTemplateMover]]
revision.text:
{{BLP sources|date=August 2017}} {{Infobox writer | name = Miren Agur Meabe | embed = | honorific_prefix = | honorific_suffix = | image = Miren_Agur_Meabe.jpg | image_size = | image_upright = | alt = | caption = | native_name = | native_name_lang = | pseudonym = | birth_name = Miren Agur Meabe Plaza | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1962|10|7|df=yes}} | birth_place = | death_date = | death_place = | resting_place = | occupation = | language = Basque | nationality = Spanish | citizenship = | education = | alma_mater = | period = | genre = | subject = | movement = | notableworks = | spouse = | partner = | children = | relatives = | awards = Literary Contest of the City Council of Lasarte-Oria
Euskadi Prize, Euskadi Saria | signature = | signature_alt = | years_active = | module = | website = | portaldisp = }} '''Miren Agur Meabe Plaza''' (born 7 October 1962) is a [[Biscay]]an writer in the [[Basque language]].{{cite web|url=http://aunamendi.eusko-ikaskuntza.eus/artikuluak/artikulua.php?id=eu&ar=96680|title=Meabe Plaza, Miren Agur - Auñamendi Eusko Entziklopedia|website=aunamendi.eusko-ikaskuntza.eus}}{{cite web|url=http://www.basqueliterature.com/es/Katalogoak/egileak/meabe|title=MEABE, Miren Agur. Portal Literatura Vasca|website=www.basqueliterature.com}} ==Life== Meabe was born in [[Lekeitio]]. She gained a diploma in Teaching by the [[Derio School of Teachers]] in the speciality of Social Sciences, graduating in Basque Philology. She worked for several years at the Ikastola Kirikino in [[Bilbao]]. Since 1990, she has also directed the Giltza-Edebé publishing house in the Basque Country. At present her work is centered on translation and literary creation.{{citation needed|date=September 2017}} As a writer, her work is developed especially around poetry and children's and young people's literature. She has been awarded several prizes.{{citation needed|date=September 2017}} Several of her works have been translated into Catalan, Spanish and Galician. Since 2006, she has been a collaborating member of The Royal Academy of the Basque-Euskaltzaindia Language. Her first story, "Uneka ... Gaba", was published in 1986. In this work, using a language very close to the lyric, we can already appreciate the characteristic features of her work: [[Symbolism (arts)|symbolism]] and the [[postmodern]] concept of the "moment": "the moment lives and we only live the moment." The self and the moment surround us.{{citation needed|date=September 2017}} Focused on poetry in 1991, she won the Literary Contest of the City Council of Lasarte-Oria with the work ''Oi hondarrezko emaikaitz''. It is a collection of poems around the myth of [[Penelope]]. The first edition went unnoticed and was edited again in the magazine ''Idatz & Mintz'' of the Institute Labayru in the year 1999.{{citation needed|date=September 2017}} Several of these poems were published later in his book of poetry more known as: ''Azalaren kodea'' (2000). In this work, as appears from her poetics, the author tries to develop a writing based on the body. The titles of the sections of the book show the different ways of expressing themselves in relation to the body: "Orbainak" (Scars), "Tatuajeak" (Tattoos) and "Kontraseinuak" (Passwords). She uses a new language of gestures and love. However, in Oharrak style is defined by accuracy, brevity and concreteness. This new vocabulary related to the woman's body is an attempt to communicate through gestures, despite being realized through the word. The author's own life is at the beginning of the poems, which conveys her message through those verses. Miren Agur Meabe also deals with children's and young people's literature, especially since the year 2000, and is the genre with which she has received the most recognition, mainly for the Euskadi Prize, Euskadi Saria, and the translation of these works: ''Itsaslabarreko Et al'' (2001). {{citation needed|date=September 2017}} It is an adventure story, with the ingredients of research and fear. ''Itsasargian urtebete'' (2006) provides a version of the civil war from a boy's point of view. It affects the passages of his life and his sensitivity to live them, especially those related to love. Unlike the work of [[Joseba Sarrionaindia]] on the same subject, Miren Agur Meabe is dedicated mainly to highlight the everyday.{{citation needed|date=September 2017}} As for the youthful poetry premiered with ''Zer da, ba, Maitasuna?'' {{clarify|date=September 2017}} == Awards == *1991 : Lasarte-Oria Town Hall Award for ''Oi hondarrezko emakaitz!'', published in 1999. *1997 : Prize Imagina Euskadi for ''Ohar orokorrak''. Poetry *2001 : Prize of the Criticism of poetry in Euskera for ''Azalaren kodea''. *2002 : Euskadi Prize for Children and Youth Literature for ''Itsaslabarreko etxea'', (The House of the Cliff) *2007 : Euskadi Award for Children and Youth Literature for ''Urtebete itsasargian'', (A year in the lighthouse) *2007 : Prize Lauaxeta awarded by the Provincial Council of Bizkaia to his career. *2008 : Liburu Gaztea Award (Young Book) for the book ''A year in the lighthouse''. *2011 : Euskadi Prize for Children and Youth Literature for ''Errepidea''. *2011 : Prize of the Critique of poetry in Euskera for ''Bitsa eskuetan''. *2012 : IBBY Honor Roll by Mila magnolia-lore. *2012 : Rosalía de Castro Award for literary career. *2013 : 111Akademiar Prize in Saria by ''Kristalezko begi bat'' *2014 : Prize Zazpikale of the Book Fair of Bilbao by the novel ''Kristalezko begi bat''. == Works == ; Children's literature *''Uneka''... Gaba (1986). *''Bisita''. (Gara, 2001). *''La casa del acantilado'' (''Itsaslaberreko etxea'', 2001), (Edebé, 2004). Translated into Spanish by the author, *''Joanes eta Bioletaren bihotza''. (Elkar, 2002). *''Amal''. 2003. *''Etxe bitan bizi naiz, eta zer?'', (Elkar, 2003) illustrations by [[Jokin Mitxelena]], San Sebastián, **Translation into gallego: ''Eu vivo en dúas casas... ¿e que?'', (Galaxia, 2003). **Translation into aragonés: ''Bibo en dos casas'', por Chabier Tomás Arias (Xordica, 2003). **Translation into catalán: ''Visc en dues cases'' (La Galera, 2003). *''Cómo corregir a una maestra malvada'' (Nola zuzendu andereño gaizto bat, 2003), (Edebé, 2003). Translation into Spanish by the author, *''Un año en el faro'' (Urtebete itsasargian, 2006). (Lóguez, 2008). Translation into Spanish by the author *''Supositorioak otsoarentzat.'' (Giltza, 2006.) *''Izar bat zopan''. (Giltza, 2008). *''Olatu guztien gainetik.'' (Ibaizabal, 2009.) *''Errepidea''. (Erein, 2010.) *''Mila magnolia lore''. (Gero-Mensajero, 2010). *''Bihotzak dun-dun''. (Elkar, 2015.) *''Ros''. (Erein, 2015). ; Poetry *''Iraila''. (Sustraia, 1984.) *''Nerudaren zazpigarren maitasun olerkiari begira''. (Sustraia, 1985.) *''Arratsezko poemak''. 1987 *''Peneloperen poemak.'' (Idatz & Mintz, 1989). *''Oi, hondarrezko emakaitz!.'' (Labayru, 1999). *''Ihesaren kantua''. (Idatz & Mintz, 2000). *''El código de la piel'' (Azalaren kodea, 2000). (Bassarai, 2002). ** Translation into catalán: ''codi de la pell'' by Maria Josep Escrivà, (Edicions 96, 2006). *''Bitsa eskuetan''. Susa, 2010. == References == {{reflist}} ==External links== {{commons category}} * {{authority control}} [[Category:1962 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:20th-century Spanish writers]] [[Category:20th-century Spanish women writers]] [[Category:21st-century Spanish writers]] [[Category:21st-century Spanish women writers]] [[Category:People from Lea-Artibai]] [[Category:Basque-language writers]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox writer | name = Mukund Parikh | image = Writer Mukund Parikh.jpg | image_size = | image_upright = | caption = At government college, Kathlal, January 2018 | pseudonym = | birth_name = Mukund Bhailal Parikh | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|df=y|1934|1|26}} | birth_place = Nadisar, [[Panchmahal district]], [[Gujarat]], India | death_date = <!-- {{Death date and age|YYYY|MM|DD|YYYY|MM|DD}} --> | death_place = | resting_place = | occupation = Poet, novelist, playwright | language = [[Gujarati language|Gujarati]] | residence = | nationality = Indian | education = B.A, LL.B | alma_mater = [[Gujarat University]] | period = modern [[Gujarati literature]] | genre = | subject = | movement = Re Math, Akanth Sabarmati | notableworks = ''Mahabhinishkraman'' (1968) | spouse = | children = | relatives = | awards = | signature = | years_active = }}
'''Mukund Parikh''' is a [[Gujarati language|Gujarati]] novelist, poet and playwright from [[Gujarat]], India.
==Life== Mukund Parikh was born on 26 January 1934 in Nadisar village (now in [[Panchmahal district]], Gujarat) to Bhailal Parikh. He completed his primary and secondary education from his native town [[Balasinor]]. He completed his B. A. in Economics from Dharmendrasinhji College, [[Rajkot]] in 1957. He worked in a Provident Fund Commissioner Office from 1954 to 1980. He studied LL.B. from [[Ahmedabad]] in 1980 from [[Gujarat University]].<ref name="Seshagiri2008">{{cite book|author=Narasimhiah Seshagiri|title=Encyclopaedia of Cities and Towns in India: Gujarat|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=IhsoAQAAIAAJ|year=2008|publisher=Gyan Publishing House|isbn=978-81-212-0981-6|page=96}}</ref> Since 1981, he is working as a lawyer.<ref name="AGSI">{{cite book|title=અર્વાચીન ગુજરાતી સાહિત્યનો ઈતિહાસ - આધુનિક અને અનુઆધુનિક યુગ|last=Brahmabhatt|first=Prasad|publisher=Parshwa Publication|year=2010|isbn=978-93-5108-247-7|location=Ahmedabad|pages=196–198|language=gu|trans-title=History of Modern Gujarati Literature – Modern and Postmodern Era}}</ref>
==Works== His ''Mahabhinishkraman'' (1968) was an experimental novel.<ref name="George1992">{{cite book|author=K. M. George|title=Modern Indian Literature, an Anthology: Surveys and poems|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=m1R2Pa3f7r0C&pg=PA141|year=1992|publisher=Sahitya Akademi|isbn=978-81-7201-324-0|page=141}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|title=The Illustrated Weekly of India|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=V7gnAQAAIAAJ|volume=101|year=1980|publisher=Times of India}}</ref> The story follows a [[love triangle]] of a character named Amit Dalal and it explores his relationship with three ladies: Chandan, his mother; Rama, his wife and Saroj, his lover. Parikh employs the [[Stream of consciousness (narrative mode)|stream of consciousness]] in his narration. He has used motifs such as [[pipal tree]] and darkness. He has explored [[Oedipus complex]] in his character's relationships. The novel was particularly praised for its language.<ref name="AGSI"/><ref name="Kendra2007">{{cite book|title=Gujarat|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=g4oMAQAAMAAJ|year=2007|publisher=Smt. Hiralaxmi Navanitbhai Shah Dhanya Gurjari Kendra, Gujarat Vishvakosh Trust|page=404}}</ref>
He was associated with the experimental literary circles such as Re Math and Akanth Sabarmati. His [[one-act play]] ''Choras Inda Ane Gol Kabaro'' was included in a collection of five one-act plays ''Make Believe'' (1968) published by Re Math. This play is considered as an example of an [[Theatre of the Absurd|absurd play]] from the early period of modern Gujarati literature. It is a psychological play flipping the places of an actor and the viewers in the theatre. ''Moksh'' (1975) is his one-act plays collection.<ref name="AGSI"/>
''Man Chitarie'' (2004) is his poetry collection awarded by [[Gujarat Sahitya Akademi]].<ref name="AGSI"/>
He co-edited poetry journal ''Shabda'' with [[Ravji Patel]].<ref>{{cite book|title=Indian Literature|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=xAUwAQAAMAAJ|accessdate=31 January 2017|date=January 2009|publisher=Sahitya Akademi.|page=263}}</ref>
==See also==
* [[List of Gujarati-language writers]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{Authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Parikh, Mukund}} [[Category:1934 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People from Panchmahal district]] [[Category:Gujarati-language poets]] [[Category:Gujarati-language writers]] [[Category:20th-century Indian novelists]] [[Category:20th-century Indian poets]] [[Category:Poets from Gujarat]] [[Category:Novelists from Gujarat]] [[Category:Gujarat University alumni]]

revision.text:
{{refimprove|date=May 2018}}
In [[mathematics]], more precisely in [[formal language theory]], the profinite words are the generalization of the notion of finite words into a [[Cauchy completion|complete topological space]]. This notion allows to use [[topology]] to study languages and finite semigroups. For example, profinite words are used to give an alternative characterization to the algebraic notion of [[variety of finite semigroups]].
==Definition==
Let '''A''' an [[Alphabet (formal languages)|alphabet]]. The set of profinite words over '''A''' consists in the [[Completion (topology)|completion]] of a metric space defined on the set <math>\hat A^*</math> of words over '''A'''. The distance used to define this metric space is defined using a notion of separation of words. Those notions are now defined.
===Separation=== Let '''M''' and '''N''' [[monoid]]s, let '''p''' and '''q''' be elements of the monoid '''M'''. Let '''φ''' a [[morphism]] of monoid from '''M''' to '''N'''. It is said that the morphism φ separates '''p''' and '''q''' if <math>\phi(p)\ne\phi(q)</math>. For example, the morphism <math>\phi:A^*\to \mathbb Z/2\mathbb Z, w\mapsto |w|</math> sending a words to the parity of its length separates the words '''ababa''' and '''abaa'''. Indeed <math>\phi(ababa)=1\ne0=\phi(abaa)</math>.
It is said that '''N''' separates '''p''' and '''q''' if there exists a morphism of monoid φ from '''M''' to '''N''' which separates '''p''' and '''q'''. Using previous example, <math>\mathbb Z/2\mathbb Z</math> separates '''ababa''' and '''abaa'''. More generally, <math>\mathbb Z/n\mathbb Z</math> separates any words whose size are not congruent modulo '''n'''. In general, any two distinct words can be separated, using the monoid whose elements are the factors of '''p''' plus a fresh element 0. The morphism sends prefixes of '''p''' to themselves and everything else to 0.
===Distance=== The distance between two distinct words '''p''' and '''q''' is defined as the inverse of the size of the least morphism '''N''' separating '''p''' and '''q'''. Thus, the distance of '''ababa''' and '''abaa''' is <math>\frac12</math>. The distance of '''p''' and itself is defined as 0.
This distance '''d''' is ultrametric, and furthermore it satisfies <math>d(uw,vw)\le d(u,v)</math> and <math>d(wu,wv)\le d(u,v)</math>.
Since any word '''p''' can be separated from any other word using a monoid with '''|p|+1''' elements, where '''|p|''' is the length of '''p''', it follows that the distance between '''p''' and any other word is at least <math>\frac{1}{|p|}</math>. Thus the topology defined by this metric is discrete. ===Profinite topology=== The profinite topology over '''A''', denoted <math>\hat A^*</math>, is the [[Completion (topology)|completion]] of the set of finite words under the distance defined above. It should be noted that the completion preserve the monoid structure.
The topology <math>\hat A^*</math> is compact.
Any monoid morphism <math>\phi:A^*\to M</math>, with '''M''' finite can be extended uniquely into a morphism <math>\hat\phi:\hat A^*\to M</math>, and this morphism is uniformly continuous. Furthermore, it is the least topological space with this property.
===Profinite word=== A profinite word is an element of the profinite topology. And a profinite language is a set of profinite word. Each finite words are profinite words. A few examples of profinite words which are not finite are now given.
For '''m''' any word, let <math>m^\omega</math> denote <math>\lim_{i\to\infty}m^{i!}</math>. Note that <math>m^{i!}</math> is a [[Cauchy sequence]]. Intuitively, to separate <math>m^{i!}</math> and <math>m^{i'!}</math>, a monoid should count at least up to <math>\min(i,i')</math>, hence requires at least <math>\min(i,i')</math> elements. Since <math>m^{i!}</math> is a [[Cauchy sequence]], <math>x^\omega</math> is indeed a profinite word.
Furthermore, the word <math>x^\omega</math> is idempotent. This is due to the fact that, for any morphism <math>\phi:A^*\to N</math> with '''N''' finite, <math>\phi(m^{i!})=\phi(m)^{i!}=n^{i!}</math> for some '''n''' belonging to '''N'''. Since '''N''' is finite, for '''i''' great enough, <math>n^{i!}</math> is idempotent, and the sequence is constant.
Similarly, <math>m^{\omega+1}</math> and <math>m^{\omega-1}</math> are defined as <math>\lim_{n\to\infty}m^{n!+ 1}</math> and <math>\lim_{n\to\infty}m^{n!-1}</math> respectively.
==Profinite languages== The notion of profinite languages allow to relate notions of [[semigroup theory]] to notions of topology. More precisely, given '''P''' a profinite language, the following statements are equivalent: *'''P''' is clopen. *'''P''' is [[recognizable_set|recognizable]], *The [[syntactic congruence]] of '''P''' is clopen, as a subset of <math>\hat A^*\times\hat A^*</math>.
Similar statements also holds for languages '''P''' of finite words. The following conditions are equivalent. *<math>P</math> is recognisable (as a subset of <math>A^*</math>), *the [[closure (topology)|closure]] of '''P''', <math>\overline P</math>, is recognisable (as a subset of <math>\hat A^*</math>), where *<math>P=K\cap A^*</math>, for some clopen '''K''', *<math>\overline P</math> is clopen.
Those characterisations are due to the more general fact that, taking the closure of a finite language, and restricting a profinite language to finite words are inverse operations, when they are applied to recognisable languages.
==References== {{cite book|last1=Pin|first1=Jean-Éric|title=Mathematical Foundations of Automata Theory|date=2016-11-30|pages=130-139|url=http://www.liafa.jussieu.fr/~jep/PDF/MPRI/MPRI.pdf}} {{cite book|last1=Almeida|first1=J|title=Finite semigroups and universal algebra|date=1994|publisher=World Scientific Publishing Co. Inc.|location=River Edge, NJ|isbn=981-02-1895-8}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Formal Language}} [[Category:Formal languages]] [[Category:Theoretical computer science]] [[Category:Topology]] [[Category:Mathematical structures]]
